revision.text:
{{Year box}} '''1848 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport.
==[[Baseball]]== '''Events''' * First publication of the [[New York Knickerbockers|Knickerbocker rules]].<ref>[http://retrosheet.org/Protoball/chron.htm Protoball 1848.1] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090809204534/http://retrosheet.org/Protoball/chron.htm |date=2009-08-09 }}. Retrieved on 7 November 2009.</ref>
==[[Boxing]]== '''Events''' * [[William Thompson (boxer)|William Thompson]] retains the Championships of England but there is no record of any fights involving him in 1848.<ref name="WT">[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/thompson.htm Cyber Boxing Zone – Bendigo]. Retrieved on 7 November 2009.</ref>
==[[Cricket]]== '''Events''' * 18 July — birth in Gloucestershire of [[W. G. Grace]], who will dominate cricket to the end of the 19th century and be hailed as ''The Great Cricketer'' '''England''' * Most runs – [[George Parr (cricketer)|George Parr]] 339 @ 18.83 (HS 52) * Most wickets – [[William Hillyer]] 85 @ 7.28 (BB 8–26)
==[[Football]]== '''Events''' * The original [[Cambridge Rules|Cambridge University Rules]] are written by a committee of students, including [[H. de Winton and J. C. Thring]], who are still confused by the different rules operating at the various schools. Besides [[Rugby School|Rugby]], [[Eton College|Eton]] and [[Harrow School|Harrow]] there are also rules of a sort in place at [[Winchester School|Winchester]], [[Shrewsbury School|Shrewsbury]] and elsewhere. Cambridge is the first attempt at codifying the rules of [[association football]] (i.e., the "dribbling" game) as distinct from [[rugby football]] (i.e., the "handling" game). * Unfortunately, no copy of these original Cambridge Rules survives.<ref>No copy of the 1848 rules has survived, the earliest written version dating from 1856; the 1863 revision of the rules played a significant part in developing the rules that became [[association football]].</ref> * The essential difference in the two codes is always that association football does not allow a player to run with the ball in his hands or pass it by hand to a colleague. However, the early rules do allow players to touch and control the ball by hand.
==[[Horse racing]]== '''England''' * [[1848 Grand National|Grand National]] – Chandler * [[1,000 Guineas Stakes]] – Canezou * [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – Flatcatcher * [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – [[Surplice (horse)|Surplice]] * [[Epsom Oaks|The Oaks]] – Cymba * [[St. Leger Stakes]] – [[Surplice (horse)|Surplice]]
==[[Lacrosse]]== '''Events''' * Montreal's Olympic Club plays a match against an indigenous team.
==[[Rowing (sport)|Rowing]]== '''The Boat Race''' * The [[Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race]] is not held this year '''Other events''' * [[Henry Clasper]] builds the first keelless racing boats and spoon shaped oars, and develops the outrigger.
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{Infobox games | Name = X Asian Games | Logo = 10th asiad.png | Size = 140 | Optional caption = | Host city = [[Seoul]], [[South Korea]] | Nations participating = 27 | Athletes participating = 4,839 | Events = 296 in 25 sports | Opening ceremony = 20 September | Closing ceremony = 5 October | Officially opened by = [[Chun Doo-hwan]]
{{small|[[President of South Korea]]}} | Officially closed by = [[Fahad Al-Ahmed Al-Jaber Al-Sabah]]
{{small|President of the [[Olympic Council of Asia]]}} | Athlete's Oath = | Judge's Oath = | Torch Lighter = {{nowrap|[[Chang Jae-guen]]{{cn|date=November 2018}}}} | Stadium = [[Seoul Olympic Stadium|Olympic Stadium]] | previous = [[1982 Asian Games|Delhi 1982]] | next = [[1990 Asian Games|Beijing 1990]] }} The '''1986 [[Asian Games]]''', also known as the '''10th Asian Games''' and the '''X Asiad''' were held from 20 September to 5 October 1986, in [[Seoul]], South Korea. The city was supposed to host the [[1970 Asian Games|1970 games]], but it received security threats from neighbouring [[North Korea]], forcing it to give up hosting the games to previous 1966 host Bangkok, Thailand. The venues and facilities of the 10th Asiad were the same [[Venues of the 1988 Summer Olympics|venues]] and facilities that would be used in the [[1988 Summer Olympics]], this was considered a test event. ==Boycotting countries== [[File:1986 Asian Games (Seoul) boycotting Asian countries (red) 01.png|thumb|300px|Boycotting countries are in dark red]] Communist states [[North Korea]], [[Mongolian People's Republic|Mongolia]], [[Vietnam]], [[Laos]], [[People's Republic of Kampuchea|Cambodia]], [[Democratic Republic of Afghanistan|Afghanistan]], and [[South Yemen]], as well as [[Socialist Republic of the Union of Burma|Burma]], [[Syria]], and [[Brunei]] all boycotted the Games for political reasons and conditions. However, the communist [[China|People's Republic of China]] competed. ==Terrorist attack== A North Korean spy [[Gimpo International Airport bombing|detonated a bomb]] behind a vending machine in [[Gimpo International Airport]] and killed five people, including a technician, just a few days before the Games started. ==Participating nations== {{col-begin}} {{col-3}} *{{FlagIOC2|BRN|1986 Asian {{cleanup-reorganize|date=May 2014}} {{Infobox football match | title = 1999 Egypt Cup Final | image = | event = [[1998–99 Egypt Cup]] | team1 = [[Zamalek SC|Zamalek]] | team1score = 3 | team2 = [[Ismaily SC|Ismaily]] | team2score = 1 | details = | date = 28 May 1999 | stadium = [[Cairo Stadium]] | city = [[Cairo]] | man_of_the_match1a = | referee = [[Alfredo Trentalange]] ([[Italian Football Federation|Italy]]) | attendance = 50,000 | weather = | previous = [[1998 Egypt Cup Final|1998]] | next = [[2000 Egypt Cup Final|2000]] }} '''1999 Egypt Cup Final''', was the final match of [[1998–99 Egypt Cup]], when [[Zamalek SC|Zamalek]] played [[Ismaily SC|Ismaily]] at [[Cairo Stadium]] in [[Cairo]]. {{Infobox horseraces |class = Group 1 |horse race = Bayerisches Zuchtrennen
Grosser Dallmayr-Preis |image = |caption = |location = Munich Racecourse
[[Munich]], Germany |inaugurated = 1866 |race type = [[Flat racing|Flat]] / [[Thoroughbred]] |sponsor = [[Dallmayr]] |website = [http://www.galoppriem.de/ Munich] |distance = 2,000 metres (1¼ miles) |surface = Turf |track = Left-handed |qualification = Three-years-old and up |weight = 55½ kg (3yo); 60 kg (4yo+)
'''Allowances'''
1½ kg for [[Filly|fillies]] and [[mare]]s |purse = €155,000 ''(2018)''
'''1st:''' €100,000 }} The '''Bayerisches Zuchtrennen''' is a [[Group races|Group 1]] [[Flat racing|flat]] [[Horse racing|horse race]] in Germany open to [[thoroughbred]]s aged three years or older. It is run at [[Munich]] over a distance of 2,000 metres (about 1¼ miles), and it is scheduled to take place each year on the last Sunday in July. ==History== The event was established in 1866, and it was originally restricted to three-year-olds. It was known as the Grosser Dreijährigen-Zuchtpreis from 1940 to 1944, and as the Bayerisches Derby in 1947. The present race grading system was introduced in Germany in 1972, and the Bayerisches Zuchtrennen was initially classed at Group 3 level. It was opened to older horses and promoted to Group 2 in 1985. It was given Group 1 status in 1990. The race has been sponsored by [[Dallmayr]] since 1996, and it is now run as the Grosser Dallmayr-Preis. ==Records== '''Most successful horse (2 wins):''' * Turfkönig – ''1989, 1990'' * Soldier Hollow – ''2005, 2007'' ---- '''Leading [[jockey]] since 1900 (7 wins):''' * Fritz Drechsler – ''Grossmogul (1948), Levantos (1953), Liebeschor (1962), Daimyo (1967), Bacchus (1968), Boris (1972), Mirando (1973)'' ---- '''Leading [[Horse trainer|trainer]] since 1940 (8 wins):''' * [[Heinz Jentzsch]] – ''Daimyo (1967), Bacchus (1968), Boris (1972), Mirando (1973), Index (1981), Anno (1982), Lirung (1985), Zampano (1987)'' ---- '''Leading owner since 1900 (9 wins):''' ''(includes part ownership)'' * August von Schmieder – ''Beowulf (1903), Herero (1907), Illo (1909), Pilgramsberg (1910), Don Cesar (1911), Flaminio (1912), Nachtschatten (1913), Drosselbart (1914), Persicus (1915)'' {{clear}} ==Winners since 1970== {| class = "sortable" | border="1" style="border-collapse: collapse; font-size:90%" |- bgcolor="#77dd77" align="center" ! {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Bridgeforth Stadium | nickname = | image = Bridgeforth Panorama.JPEG | image_size = 200px | caption = Bridgeforth Panorama | former_names = Madison Stadium (1975–1981)
JMU Stadium (1981–1989) | location = Champions Dr.
[[Harrisonburg, Virginia|Harrisonburg, VA]] 22801 | broke_ground = 1973 | built = | opened = September 20, 1975{{cite web |url=http://www.fanbase.com/James-Madison-Dukes-Football-1975 |title=Archived Document |accessdate=2011-10-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141207131736/http://www.fanbase.com/James-Madison-Dukes-Football-1975 |archivedate=2014-12-07 |df= }} | expanded = 1981, 2011 | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[James Madison University]] | operator = [[James Madison University]] | surface = [[Astroturf]], 1975–2005
[[FieldTurf]], 2006–present | construction_cost = $62 million (expansion) | architect = [[HKS, Inc.]] (Sports Design – expansion), Moseley Architects (Architect of Record – expansion) | tenants = [[James Madison Dukes football]] (1975-present) | seating_capacity = 24,877 (2011–present){{cite news |title=Game Preview Capsules for ODU, JMU, Norfolk State|url=http://www.timesdispatch.com/sports/college/football/game-preview-capsules-for-odu-jmu-norfolk-state/article_97067815-2c83-5802-a397-7c2759a1d1e5.html|newspaper=[[Richmond Times-Dispatch]]|date=August 31, 2013|accessdate=September 7, 2013}}
15,694 (2010)
15,778 (2008–2009)
13,559 (2001–2007)
12,500 (1981–2000)
5,200 (1975–1980) }} '''Bridgeforth Stadium''' is a [[American football|football]] stadium located on the campus of [[James Madison University]] in [[Harrisonburg, Virginia]]. The stadium is home to the [[James Madison Dukes football]] team. The playing surface is named '''Zane Showker Field'''. Bridgeforth Stadium, with a seating capacity of 24,877, is currently the largest stadium in the [[Colonial Athletic Association]] and 13th largest at the [[NCAA Division I#Football Championship Subdivision|NCAA Football Championship Subdivision]] (FCS) level. ==History== Originally named '''Madison Stadium''', it was built in 1975 and had a capacity of approximately 5,200.[http://www.jmu.edu/centennialcelebration/hillside.shtml The Hillside Gang] James Madisum University Retrieved July 21, 2011 The stadium was originally designed as a multi-purpose facility, and hosted football, track and field, lacrosse, and field hockey events. In addition, the stadium contained indoor racquetball courts, several classrooms, support space for the JMU ROTC program, and administrative offices for JMU varsity athletic teams and media relations. In 1981, the stadium then called '''JMU Stadium''', underwent its first expansion which included a second set of seats giving it a total capacity of more than 12,000. The stadium was again renamed in 1990 for William E. Bridgeforth, former member of the JMU Board of Visitors. In 2003 the field was named in honor of JMU benefactor Zane Showker (whose name is also on the building for JMU's School of Business). In 2004, the university added a new scoreboard with video replay features, which was dismantled after the 2010 season as part of a significant renovation of the entire facility. It was replaced by a much larger video scoreboard behind the south endzone. In 2006, the existing artificial turf was replaced with [[FieldTurf]]. The stadium is situated in the Lakeside area of campus, and is adjacent to the multimillion-dollar Plecker Athletic Center and a five story parking deck."[http://www.jmusports.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=14400&ATCLID=785406 Bridgeforth Stadium/Zane Showker Field] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110720114958/http://www.jmusports.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=14400&ATCLID=785406 |date=July 20, 2011 }}." James Madison Athletics Retrieved November 13, 2011. ==Renovation== A major stadium renovation and expansion project began in December 2009. The expansion included the demolition of the then existing west stands, removal of the track, and the construction of a $62 million, two-tiered complex in its place.http://www.nbc29.com/story/13009074/jmu-debuts-football-stadium-expansion After completion in August 2011, Bridgeforth Stadium's seating capacity was raised to 24,877 permanent seats. In addition to increased seating, the expansion included the construction of a larger video and scoreboard, the addition of 17 suites, a club lounge with chairback seating, and increased stadium lighting. All total, the completion of the Bridgeforth Stadium and Zane Showker Field complex, including the Plecker Athletic Performance Center and parking deck, represents an investment of approximately $90 million. On September 10, 2011, the [[2011 James Madison Dukes football team|Dukes]] played for the first time in the newly expanded stadium. In front of a sellout crowd of 25,102 fans, the Dukes defeated the Blue Devils of [[Central Connecticut State University]] by a score of 14–9. [[File:JMU Bridgeforth Fieldturf.JPG|thumb|Bridgeforth Stadium in 2007]] ==Notable games== Some of the recent notable games in JMU history that have been played at Bridgeforth Stadium are: *The 20–13 victory over University of Delaware in 2004 *The 2008 35–32 victory over Appalachian State *The 38–35 victory over Wofford in the first round of the 2008 FCS playoffs *The 31–27 victory over Villanova in the second round of the 2008 FCS playoffs *The 2010 victory over the FCS #1 William and Mary, 30–24 *The 14–9 victory over Central Connecticut State in the 2011 debut of the newly renovated Bridgeforth Stadium *The 27–26 double overtime victory over William & Mary, the 31–24 come back victory over William & Mary *The 2015 59–49 loss against Richmond in front of a record 26,069 fans on the heels of a visit from ESPN's ''[[College GameDay (football)|College GameDay]]'' *The 2015 38–29 win over Villanova clinching JMUs first CAA football title since 2008 *The record setting 84–7 win over Rhode Island in 2016. *The 2016 55–20 win over New Hampshire in the FCS Second round *The 2016 65–7 win over Sam Houston State in the FCS Quarterfinals *A 30–8 win over Villanova in 2017 on the heels of a return visit from ''College GameDay'' *A 51-16 win over South Dakota State in the 2017 FCS Semifinals to send JMU to their second consecutive FCS National Championship Game ==See also== * [[List of NCAA Division I FCS football stadiums]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category|Bridgeforth Stadium and Zane Showker Field}} * [http://www.jmu.edu/bridgeforthstadium/?KEY=&DB_OEM_ID=14400&DB_LANG=&IN_SUBSCRIBER_CONTENT=Bridgeforth Stadium Expansion] {{James Madison University}} {{James Madison Dukes football navbox}} {{Colonial Athletic Association football venue navbox}} {{Virginia college football venues}} {{coord|38|26|7|N|78|52|23|W|type:landmark|display=title}} [[Category:College football venues]] [[Category:1975 establishments in Virginia]]

{{Infobox Weapon |name=CZ 75 Tactical Sports |origin= [[Czechoslovakia]]
[[Czech Republic]] |type=Competition [[Semi-automatic pistol]] |is_ranged=yes |service=2005–present |used_by= |wars= |manufacturer=[[Česká Zbrojovka Uherský Brod|Česká Zbrojovka]] |production_date=2005–present |number= 30.000+ |weight= 1.3 kg (2.47 [[Avoirdupois|lb]] |cartridge= [[9×19mm Parabellum]]
[[.40 S&W]] |action= [[Recoil operation|short recoil]], tilting barrel |rate= [[Semi-automatic pistol|semi-automatic]] |velocity= |range=50 m (for 9mm CZ-75 family and CZ-75 Automatic) |max_range= |feed= detachable box magazine |sights= Front blade, rear square notch }} The '''CZ 75 Tactical Sports''' pistol [http://www.cz-usa.com/products/view/cz-75-tactical/ > CZ 75 Tactical Sport]. CZ-USA. Retrieved on 2011-06-09. is a Czech single-action firearm specifically designed for practical shooting competitions. It is the successor of the [[CZ 75]] Standard IPSC model. Though almost identical in external appearance, the TS features some improvements, especially in its trigger mechanism, magazine capacity and durability. Originally, the CZ 75 IPSC models were manufactured in versions for two IPSC practical shooting divisions: Modified (the 75 M IPSC) and Standard (the 75 ST IPSC). Currently, there are no CZ models available for Modified Division. Recently CZ introduced the CZ 75 TS Czechmate [http://www.cz-usa.com/products/view/czechmate/ > CZ 75 TS Czechmate] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110227211700/http://www.cz-usa.com/products/view/czechmate/# |date=2011-02-27 }}. CZ-USA. Retrieved on 2011-06-09. a competition variant based on the Tactical Sports [[9mm]] model; equipped with a compensator and electronic [[red dot sight]] on a frame mount; designed especially for IPSC Open Division. The CZ 75 TS comes in two [[caliber]]s: [[.40 S&W]] (17 [[Cartridge (firearms)|cartridge]]s in the magazine) and [[9mm]] (20 [[Cartridge (firearms)|cartridge]]s in the magazine). The [[.40 S&W]] [[caliber]] offers a score advantage by considering a higher or “major” [[caliber]] (according to the IPSC rules). However, the 9mm model is appealing to shooters who do not reload their ammo and in countries where the law does not allow the use of major calibers, as well as for those who want to take advantage of the low recoil and very high magazine capacity of the [[9mm]] version. CZ Custom has marketed a magazine extender for the [[.40 S&W]] version that increases capacity from 17 to 20 cartridges,[http://czcustom.com/cztacticalsportextendedbasepadsilverspring-1.aspx CZ TS Extended Base Pad BK] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101127023212/http://czcustom.com/cztacticalsportextendedbasepadsilverspring-1.aspx# |date=2010-11-27 }}. Czcustom.com. Retrieved on 2011-06-09. but with this accessory the pistol is no longer legal in IPSC Standard Division, though it is eligible for USPSA Limited Division. == References == {{reflist}} [[Category:Semi-automatic pistols of Czechoslovakia]] [[Category:9mm Parabellum semi-automatic pistols]] [[Category:Machine pistols]] [[Category:Shooting sports equipment]]

{{National football association | Logo = | Founded = 1986 | FIBA affiliation = 1988 | Region = [[FIBA]] | Region affiliation = 1988 | President = Kitana Cabral | Coach = | }} [[File:V_SDC10039.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Pavilhão Desportivo Vavá Duarte, home of the basketball federation]][[File:V_SDC10040.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Inside the Gimnodesportivo Vava Duarte arena]] The '''Cape Verdean Basketball Federation''' (''Federação Caboverdiana de Basquetebol'') is the basketball association in Cape Verde. It is located in the capital city of [[Praia]] at [[Gimnodesportivo Vava Duarte]] in the neighborhood of [[Gamboa, Praia|Chã das Areias]], also the volleyball and the [[Cape Verdean Athletics Federation|athletics]] federation are house there. Its current president is Kitana Cabral.
==History== The popularity of basketball in Cape Verde did not grow until the country's independence in 1975.
The FCBB became was founded in 1986 and became affiliated to [[FIBA]] in 1988.
==About the federation== The basketball federation has the [[Basketball in Cape Verde|national championship]], it is one of the remaining countries in the world that uses the old system of qualification, where the winner of each island (two zones in the island of Santiago) qualify and has the group system and the knockout stage as does in football (soccer), volleyball and futsal, it had seven teams in 2011<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rtc.cv/index.php?paginas=13&id_cod=11689|title=2011 Cape Verdean Basketball Championships winner|publisher=[[RTC (Cape Verde)|TCV]]|language=pt|date=1 August 2011|accessdate=25 August 2015}}</ref> and may have eight or nine teams today. [[AD Bairro]] (or ADESBA) won the title in 2015 and was the first club to play at the continental level.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://desporto.sapo.pt/basquetebol/cabo_verde/artigo/2015/07/12/bairro-e-campeao-de-cabo-verde|title=Bairro e campeão de Cabo Verde|trans-title=Bairro, Capeverdean Champions|newspaper=SAPO PT|language=pt|date=12 July 2015|accessdate=25 August 2015}}</ref>
Cape Verde has 43 basketball teams. As of August 2015, there were 1,620 registered male players in the federation. Of which 2,000 are unregistered players<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fiba.com/pages/eng/fc/FIBA/fibaStru/nfLeag/p/nationalfederationnumber/2603/nfProf.html|title=Profile of FCBB at the FIBA website|accessdate=25 August 2015}}</ref>
==Regional federations== The federation has about 11 regional federations including: *[[Boa Vista, Cape Verde|Boa Vista]] Regional Basketball Federation (''ARBBV'' - ''Associação Regional de Basquete(bol) da Boa Vista'') - which includes the nearby island of [[Maio, Cape Verde|Maio]], that island probably has its own federation *[[Fogo, Cape Verde|Fogo]] Regional Basketball Federation (''ARBF'' - ''Associação Regional de Basquetebol do Fogo'') - which includes the nearby island of [[Brava, Cape Verde|Brava]] *[[Sal, Cape Verde|Sal]] Regional Basketball Federation (''ARBS'' - ''Associação Regional de Basquetebol do Sal'') *[[Santiago, Cape Verde|Santiago]] North Regional Basketball Federation (''ARBSN'' - ''Associação Regional de Basquetebol de Santiago Norte'') *[[Santiago, Cape Verde|Santiago]] South Regional Basketball Federation (''ARBSS'' - ''Associação Regional de Basquetebol de Santiago Sul'') *[[Santo Antão, Cape Verde|Santo Antão]] Regional Basketball Federation (''ARBSA'' - ''Associação Regional de Basquetebol de Santo Antão'') *[[São Nicolau, Cape Verde|São Nicolau]] Regional Basketball Federation (''ARBSN'' - ''Associação Regional de Basquetebol de São Nicolau'') *[[São Vicente, Cape Verde|São Vicente]] Regioinal Basketball Federation (''ARBSV'' - ''Associação Regional de Basquetebol de São Vicente'')
==See also== *[[Basketball in Cape Verde]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[https://www.facebook.com/pages/FCBB-Federa%C3%A7%C3%A3o-Caboverdiana-de-Basquetebol/153005494894993?sk=info&tab=page_info Website of the federation at Facebook] {{pt icon}} *[http://www.fiba.com/pages/eng/fc/FIBA/fibaStru/nfLeag/p/nationalfederationnumber/2603/nfProf.html Federação Caboverdiana de Basquetebol (Capeverdean Basketball Federation) at the FIBA homepage]

{{Multiple issues| {{Notability|Films|date=March 2015}} {{refimprove|date=March 2015}} }} {{Infobox film | name = Champions of Faith | director = Tom Allen | producer = John Morales
[[Lino Rulli]] | starring = [[Mike Piazza]]
[[Jeff Suppan]]
[[Mike Sweeney]]
[[Jack McKeon]] | music = Stephen Kaminski | distributor = [[Invincible Pictures US]] | released = 15 July 2008 | runtime = 99 minutes | language = English }} '''''Champions of Faith''''' (or '''''Champions of Faith: Baseball Edition''''') is a [[direct-to-video]] 2008 [[Documentary film|documentary]], based on [[Major League Baseball]] players and how their faith has strengthened their careers. ==Plot== ''Champions of Faith: Baseball Edition'' is a [[documentary film]] that showcases the intersection of [[sports]] and [[faith]] in [[Major League Baseball]] by profiling many of the most accomplished and devout figures in the game. Major League baseball's [[Mike Piazza]], [[David Eckstein]], [[Jeff Suppan]], [[Mike Sweeney]], [[Jack McKeon]] and [[Rich Donnelly]] lead the cast in this sports special that tells the story of how their faith plays a role not only on the field but at home.{{cite web | title = USCCB: 'Champions' on the field, and in their faith, highlighted on DVD | url=http://www.nccbuscc.org/movies/newdvdvideo/championsoffaithbaseball.shtml| accessdate = 2008-05-21 }} ==Cast== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Role ! Actor |- | '''Himself''' | [[Mike Piazza]] |- | '''Himself''' | [[David Eckstein]] |- | '''Himself''' | [[Jeff Suppan]] |- | '''Himself''' | [[Mike Sweeney]] |- | '''Himself''' | [[Jack McKeon]] |- | '''Himself''' | [[Rich Donnelly]] |- | '''Himself''' | [[Craig Biggio]] |- | '''Himself''' | [[Juan Pierre]] |- | '''Himself''' | [[Jim Leyland]] |- | '''Himself''' | [[Tom Glavine]] |- | '''Himself''' | [[Mike Scioscia]] |- | '''Himself''' | [[Iván Rodríguez]] |- | '''Himself''' | [[Darrell Miller]] |- | '''Himself''' | Chris Speier |- | '''Himself''' | [[Mark Teahen]] |} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb title|1017429}} {{Lino Rulli}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Champions Of Faith}} [[Category:2008 films]] [[Category:2008 direct-to-video films]] [[Category:2000s documentary films]] [[Category:2000s sports films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American documentary films]] [[Category:Documentary films about baseball]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Documentary films about Christianity in the United States]] {{sport-documentary-film-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2016}} {{Use British English|date=October 2016}} {{Infobox venue | name = Dudley Wood Stadium | nickname = | image = | fullname = | location = Dudley Wood Road, [[Dudley]], [[West Midlands (county)|West Midlands]] | coordinates = 52°28'32.3"N 2°05'06.1"W | broke_ground = | built = | opened = 1947 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = 1995 | demolished = | owner = | operator = | surface = | Manager = | architect = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names = | tenants = Greyhound racing & speedway | capacity = | dimensions = | scoreboard = }}
'''Dudley Wood Stadium''' also known as '''Cradley Heath Greyhound Stadium'''<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.old-maps.co.uk/#/Map/394322/286414/12/100954|title=OS Plan 1958-1959|publisher=old-maps.co.uk}}</ref> was a [[greyhound racing]] and [[Motorcycle speedway|speedway]] stadium.<ref name=HBS>Bamford, R & Jarvis J.(2001). ''Homes of British Speedway''. {{ISBN|0-7524-2210-3}}</ref>
==Origins== The origins of the track date back to 1917 when the Cradley Heath St Lukes Football Club built a new ground after the First World War because the lease at their previous ground had expired. They found farmland that was suitable for a pitch and constructed a basic football ground and stadium east of the Dudley Wood Road.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.old-maps.co.uk/#/Map/394322/286414/12/100734|title=OS County Series Staffordshire 1939|publisher=old-maps.co.uk}}</ref>
==Speedway== [[Cradley Heath Heathens|Cradley Heath]] speedway team first raced at the stadium on 21 June 1947. The [[Speedway National League Division Three|third division]] "Cubs" became the "Heathens" in the [[Speedway National League Division Two|National League Division Two]] in 1949, and raced continuously until 1952. In 1959 the track reopened for one unlicensed meeting and in 1960 the Heathens entered the newly formed [[Speedway Provincial League|Provincial League]]. The club then operated continuously, at top flight level from 1965, until 1995 when they were evicted by the new landlords who had bought the stadium to redevelop into housing.<ref name="HBS"/>
==Greyhound Racing== ===Opening=== Cradley St Lukes were in debt and after [[World War II|war]] a betting licence was obtained and Cradley Heath Enterprises started work on the stadium that would include a speedway track. The football club successfully gained permission from [[Stanley Rous]] ([[The Football Association|Football Association]]) to play on a ground that also held the other sports on the proviso that they did not interfere with the running of the club. So in December 1947 the racing started and the football club decided to sell the ground to the greyhound company for £3,500.<ref>{{cite book|last=Genders|first=Roy|title=The Encyclopedia of Greyhound Racing|pages =45–46|year=1981|publisher=Pelham Books Ltd|isbn=07207-1106-1}}</ref>
===History=== Racing continued throughout the 1950s as an independent track (unaffiliated to a governing body) and the football club moved out in 1960. During this time the track continued to apply to the [[National Greyhound Racing Club]] (NGRC) for a full licence without success, the first application had been in 1948 had been refused and subsequent applications had all been refused. Finally in 1966 the track then under the management of Fred Jeffcott received the news that they would be under the NGRC banner by the end of the year. NGRC racing began in September 1966 under the supervision of Racing Manager Lionel Clemmow and a new competition called the Golden Hammer was inaugurated in 1968. The first winner of the event was Shannon Water from Perry Barr. The event was suspended after the 1972 running until 1983 due to the fact that the track flittered in and out of NGRC status.<ref>{{cite book|last=Genders|first=Roy|title=NGRC book of Greyhound Racing|pages =25–26|year=1990|publisher=Pelham Books Ltd|isbn=0-7207-1804-X}}</ref>
Derek Pugh a former [[Monmore Green Stadium|Monmore]] trainer purchased the track and introduced the popular Cradley sales trials during the eighties as the auctioneers Hall, Wateridge and Owen held regular events. The Bridgewater family also had a stake in the company and despite the limitations of the venue there were eight bookmakers, a manual tote and automatic ray timing. Racing was held on Tuesday and Friday nights with trials on Wednesday mornings, the circumference of the circuit was 413 metres with distances of 231, 272, 462 and 647 metres behind an 'Outside McGee' hare.<ref>{{cite book|last=Barnes|first=Julia|title=Daily Mirror Greyhound Fact File|page =90|year=1988|publisher=Ringpress Books|isbn=0-948955-15-5}}</ref>
===Success=== Pineapple Choice won the 1980 Stow Marathon, Red Prim trained by Jim Barrett claimed the 1981 [[Eclipse (greyhounds)|Eclipse Stakes]]. Michael and Barbara Compton's Pineapple Barrow reached the 1982 [[English Greyhound Derby]] final and won the [[St Mungo Cup]], the Ken Reynolds trained Slender Boy was victorious in the 1983 Northern Flat and the puppy Glenamona lifted the 1983 [[Trafalgar Cup]].
==Closure== Cradley Heath closed its doors in 1995<ref>{{cite web|url=http://greyhoundstar.co.uk/remember-when-march-3/|title=Remember When - March|publisher=Greyhound Star}}</ref>and the stadium was demolished in 1998 by the new owners ([[Barratt Developments|Barratt Homes]]), despite not receiving planning permission for their home development project.<ref name="CH">{{cite web| last =| first =| authorlink =| coauthors =| title =Public Inquiry Justice but still no End in Sight| work =| publisher =Cradley Heath Speedway| date =| url =http://heathens.mysite.orange.co.uk/wood3.htm| doi =| accessdate =2007-11-13| deadurl =yes| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20071026025454/http://heathens.mysite.orange.co.uk/wood3.htm| archivedate =26 October 2007| df =dmy-all}}</ref>
==External links== *[http://www.cradleyspeedway.co.uk Cradley Heath Speedway website]
== References == {{Reflist}}

{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Eddy Blackman Stadion | nickname = | image = | location = [[Livorno, Suriname|Livorno]], [[Suriname]] | coordinates = {{coord|5|46|29|N|55|10|21|W|type:landmark}} | broke_ground = | opened = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Paramaribo|City and District of Paramaribo]] | operator = Livorno Sport Organisatie | surface = [[Grass]] | construction_cost = | architect = Badrinath Durga | former_names = | tenants = [[SCSV Takdier Boys|Takdier Boys]]
[[SV Jai Hanuman|Jai Hanuman]]
[[SCSV Kamal Dewaker|Kamal Dewaker]] | seating_capacity = 2,000 | dimensions = |}} '''Eddy Blackman Stadion''' is a multi-purpose stadium in [[Livorno, Suriname|Livorno]], [[Suriname]]. It is home to [[SVB Hoofdklasse]] club [[SCSV Takdier Boys]] and [[SVB Eerste Klasse]] outfits, [[SV Jai Hanuman]] and [[SCSV Kamal Dewaker]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.worldstadiums.com/south_america/countries/suriname.shtml |title=Stadiums in Suriname |publisher=Worldstadiums.com |accessdate=4 February 2016}} The stadium was built by Badrinath Durga, who has been committed to the social development of Livorno for many years. ==Location== The Eddy Blackman Stadium is located in the Northwest of Livorno on the Botromankiweg right off of the Martin Luther Kingweg, just south of the capital city [[Paramaribo]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.estadios.org/suriname/7916/eddy-blackman-stadion/ |title=Eddy Blackman Stadion |publisher=Estadios.org|accessdate=8 February 2016}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{Football venues in Suriname}} {{Hoofdklasse (suriname)}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Eddy Blackman Stadion}} [[Category:Football venues in Suriname]] [[Category:Athletics (track and field) venues in Suriname]] [[Category:Multi-purpose stadiums in Suriname]] {{Suriname-sports-venue-stub}}

revision.text:
{{good article}} The '''fair catch kick''' is a rule at the professional and high school levels of [[American football]] that allows a team that has just made a [[fair catch]] to attempt a free kick{{refn|Although the [[National Football League]] (NFL) does not consider the play a free kick, the [[National Federation of State High School Associations]] (NFHS) and media analysts regard it as being a free kick.|group=upper-alpha|name=a}} from the spot of the catch. The kick must be either a [[place kick]] or a [[drop kick]], and if it passes over the crossbar and between the goalposts of the defensive team's goal, a [[Field goal (American and Canadian football)|field goal]], worth three points, is scored to the offensive team.
The fair catch kick has its origins in [[rugby football]]. The rule is considered to be obscure and unusual, as most fair catches are made well out of [[field goal range]], and in most cases a team that has a fair catch within theoretical range will attempt a normal drive to score a [[touchdown]]. The fair catch kick is generally used when a team has fair caught a ball within field goal range and there is insufficient time to score a touchdown. At the professional level, the last successful fair catch kick was made in 1976.
==Rule== The fair catch kick rule states that, after a player has successfully made a fair catch or has been awarded a fair catch (as the result of a penalty such as kick catch interference), their team can attempt a kick from the spot of the catch;<ref name="NFHS Rulebook, p. 46.">NFHS Rulebook, p. 46.</ref><ref>NFL Rules, p. 55.</ref> the [[National Federation of State High School Associations|NFHS]] also allows a kick to be made if the down following the fair catch or awarded fair catch has to be replayed.<ref name="NFHS Rulebook, p. 46." /> Prior to the kick, the opposing team must be lined up at least ten yards beyond the spot of the ball.<ref name="NFHS Rulebook, p. 52.">NFHS Rulebook, p. 52.</ref><ref name="NFL Rules, p. 59">NFL Rules, p. 59.</ref> The kick itself can be either a [[place kick]] or [[drop kick]];<ref>NFHS Rulebook, p. 32.</ref><ref>NFL Rules, p. 57.</ref> a [[Tee#Kicking tee|kicking tee]] cannot be used at the professional level, but use of a tee up to two inches in height is permitted at the high school level.<ref name="NFL Rules, p. 59" /><ref>NFHS Rulebook, pp. 15, 32.</ref> Like other field goal attempts, the kicking team is awarded three points if the kick goes above the crossbar and between the goalposts of the opposing team's goal and did not touch a player of the offensive team after the kick.<ref>NFHS Rulebook, pp. 55, 66.</ref><ref>NFL Rules, p. 56-59.</ref> If the attempt fails, the opposing team is awarded control of the ball from the spot of the kick.<ref>NFHS Rulebook, p. 37.</ref><ref name="NFL Rules, p. 58.">NFL Rules, p. 58.</ref> The opposing team can also return the kick if it does not go out of bounds.<ref name="NFHS Rulebook, p. 52."/><ref name="NFL Rules, p. 58." />
In the [[National Federation of State High School Associations]] (NFHS) rulebook, the fair catch kick is specifically defined as a free kick.<ref>NFHS Rulebook, p. 55.</ref> The [[National Football League]] (NFL) rulebook specifically states that the fair catch kick is not a free kick,<ref name="NFL Rules, p. 59" /> instead considering the fair catch kick to be a distinct type of kick.<ref>NFL Rules, p. 13.</ref> Despite this, reporters at both levels describe the fair catch kick as a free kick.<ref name="Bears shocked Packers with last-minute free kick" /><ref name="Rackers Botches Fair Catch Kick">{{cite web|url=http://profootballtalk.nbcsports.com/2008/11/23/rackers-botches-fair-catch-kick/|title=Rackers Botches Fair Catch Kick|last=Smith|first=Michael Davi|date=November 23, 2008|publisher=[[Profootballtalk.com|Pro Football Talk]]. [[NBC Sports]]|accessdate=June 10, 2013}}</ref><ref name="Rare free kick leads to huge, last-minute win in Miami">{{cite web|url=https://ca.sports.yahoo.com/highschool/blog/prep_rally/post/Rare-free-kick-leads-to-huge-last-minute-win-in?urn=highschool-wp7579|title=Rare free kick leads to huge, last-minute win in Miami|last=Smith|first=Cameron|publisher=[[Yahoo! Sports]]|accessdate=June 10, 2013}}</ref>
==History== The fair catch kick found in [[American football]] originated in [[rugby football]]. A similar rule in rugby, the [[goal from mark]], allowed a player who had fair caught a ball to attempt an uncontested free kick from the spot of the fair catch. Both major codes of rugby have eliminated the rule; [[rugby league]] abolished the goal from mark in 1922, and [[rugby union]] removed it in 1977.<ref name="The Rarest Play in the NFL">{{cite web|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/sports/sports_nut/2013/02/fair_catch_kick_we_came_tantalizingly_close_to_seeing_the_rarest_play_in.html|title=The Rarest Play in the NFL|last=Pet|first=Brian|date=February 4, 2013|work=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]|accessdate=June 9, 2013}}</ref> [[Australian rules football]] has retained the rule, and it is a vital part of the Australian game; a "fair catch" of a ball kicked more than 15 metres in the air is called a "[[Mark (Australian football)|mark]]", and the player making the mark is then awarded a free kick.<ref>{{cite web|last=Australian Football League|title=Laws of Australian Football 2013|url=http://www.afl.com.au/staticfile/AFL%20Tenant/AFL/Static%20Files/Laws-of-Australian-Football-2013.pdf|publisher=Australian Football League|accessdate=5 November 2013}}</ref> The fair catch kick has been present in the [[National Football League]] (NFL) rulebook since the league's inception,<ref name="Bears shocked Packers with last-minute free kick">{{cite web|url=http://www.chicagobears.com/news/article-1/Bears-shocked-Packers-with-last-minute-free-kick/3D918F1C-7F1F-4740-AB17-D213D2398015|title=Bears shocked Packers with last-minute free kick|last=Mayer|first=Larry|date=March 9, 2012|publisher=[[Chicago Bears|ChicagoBears.com]]|accessdate=June 9, 2013}}</ref> and also remains in the [[National Federation of State High School Associations]] (NFHS) rulebook.<ref>Nelson 1993, p. 235.</ref> The fair catch kick is not legal in [[National Collegiate Athletics Association]] (NCAA) football; the NCAA abolished the fair catch in 1950, but re-added it a year later. When the fair catch returned to the rulebook, however, the option to attempt a kick after the fair catch was removed.<ref>Nelson 1993, pp. 233-235.</ref>
==Usage== The fair catch kick rule is very rarely invoked,<ref name="Bears shocked Packers with last-minute free kick" /><ref name="Rare free kick leads to huge, last-minute win in Miami" /><ref name="The Rarest Play in the NFL" /> and is one of the rarest plays in football.<ref name="Rare free kick leads to huge, last-minute win in Miami" /><ref name="The Rarest Play in the NFL" /> The rule has been regarded as "obscure",<ref name="Bears shocked Packers with last-minute free kick" /><ref name="Rackers Botches Fair Catch Kick" /> "bizarre",<ref name="The Rarest Play in the NFL" /> and "quirky".<ref name="Fair catch kick would add old-time pizzazz to playoffs">{{cite web|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/ron-kantowski/fair-catch-kick-would-add-old-time-pizzazz-playoffs|title=Fair catch kick would add old-time pizzazz to playoffs|last=Kantowski|first=Ron|date=January 14, 2012|work=[[Las Vegas Review-Journal]]|accessdate=June 10, 2013}}</ref> A unique set of circumstances is required for a fair catch kick to be a viable option. For one, the fair catch would need to be made at a point on the field where a field goal attempt has a reasonable chance of being successful;<ref name="Ron Pexa: What About That Call?" /> most fair catches are made well outside of [[field goal range]] (even more so since 1974, when the goal posts were moved back to the end line, adding 10 yards to such attempts).<ref name="The little-known fair catch kick">{{cite web|url=http://www.jsonline.com/blogs/sports/105908943.html|title=The little-known fair catch kick|last=Radcliffe|first=JR|date=October 27, 2010|work=[[Milwaukee Journal Sentinel]]|accessdate=June 10, 2013}}</ref> Furthermore, for a fair catch kick to be a viable option near the end of the fourth quarter, the team attempting the kick needs to be either tied or behind by three points or fewer; even if a game is tied, a fair catch kick might be unpalatable, as it is possible the ball lands in the field of play and the opponent returns it for a touchdown (which is why, when the possibility of a 75-yard fair catch kick arose in [[Super Bowl LI]], the idea was nixed).<ref name="DeCosta">{{cite news|url=https://www.boston.com/sports/new-england-patriots/2017/02/06/bill-belichick-passed-up-an-opportunity-to-end-super-bowl-51-in-the-weirdest-possible-way|title=Bill Belichick passed up an opportunity to end Super Bowl 51 in the weirdest possible way|first=Nick|last=DeCosta-Klipa|work=The Boston Globe|date=February 7, 2017|accessdate=February 7, 2017}}</ref> In exceptional circumstances a team might try the kick at the end of the first half if only a few seconds remained, but [[Art McNally]], who led the officiating department of the National Football League from 1968 to 1990, notes that, even in the event a fair catch is made within field goal range, most teams would attempt to score a [[touchdown]] unless there is not enough time left to score one.<ref name="Monolithic Packers-Bears Rivalry Evokes Numerous Memories ">{{cite web|url=http://www0.nfl.packers.com/news/stories/2004/09/16/2/?i=2004/09/16/2/|title=Monolithic Packers-Bears Rivalry Evokes Numerous Memories |date=September 16, 2004|publisher=[[Green Bay Packers|Packers.com]]|accessdate=June 10, 2013}}</ref> Accordingly, most fair catch kick attempts occur when a team has fair-caught a ball from a punt from deep in their opponent's territory, and there is not enough time left in the half to go for a touchdown.<ref name="The Rarest Play in the NFL" />
Despite its drawbacks, there are several advantages to using the fair catch kick. Because the defense is required to be ten yards beyond the spot of the kick, the kicker can take a running start before kicking as opposed to the typical two steps taken on regular field goal attempts. Similarly, the kicker does not have to worry about a low snap because the ball is not snapped. The defense is not able to block the kick, allowing the kicker to give the ball a lower trajectory than usual. The fair catch kick would also be of a shorter distance than a normal field goal attempt from the same spot, because the fair catch kick is taken from the spot of the catch, while a typical field goal is taken seven yards back from the [[line of scrimmage]].<ref name="Ron Pexa: What About That Call?">{{cite web|url=http://www.eiherald.com/artman2/publish/sports/Ron_Pexa_What_About_That_Call_November_20_200808463_printer.shtml|title=Ron Pexa: What About That Call?|last=Pexa|first=Ron|date=November 28, 2008|work=[[East Iowa Herald]]|accessdate=June 10, 2013}}</ref>
==Known attempts in the NFL== The following tables contain all confirmed fair catch kick attempts in the NFL; the NFL does not keep a record of fair catch kick attempts, so the true number of attempts is unknown.<ref name="Monolithic Packers-Bears Rivalry Evokes Numerous Memories " /> Out of the twenty-four recorded fair catch kick attempts in non-exhibition games, only six were successful; all five known attempts in exhibition games were unsuccessful. With the exception of the second recorded attempt, which was made in the 3rd quarter, all fair catch kick attempts were made within the last thirty seconds of either the 2nd or 4th quarter. The last successful attempt was made in 1976 by [[Ray Wersching]] of the [[San Diego Chargers]] (45 yards), and the longest successful attempt was made in 1964 by [[Paul Hornung]] of the [[Green Bay Packers]] (52 yards). The most recent fair catch kick attempt was by [[San Francisco 49ers]] kicker [[Phil Dawson]], who missed a 71-yard fair catch kick on September 26, 2013. In 2017, with 3 seconds left in the fourth quarter of [[Super Bowl LI]], the [[New England Patriots]] declined an opportunity to attempt a 75-yard fair catch kick, which would have won the game if successful, because of the risk of a return if the kick came up short.<ref name="DeCosta"/>
===Regular season and post-season games=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders sortable" border="1" style="align:center; font-size:90%;" |+List of known fair catch kick attempts in regular and post-season games{{refn|The games included are only confirmed instances; the NFL does not keep record of individual fair catch kicks, and the exact number of attempts is unknown.<ref name="Monolithic Packers-Bears Rivalry Evokes Numerous Memories " />|group=upper-alpha}} !scope="col" width=100|Date !scope="col" width=100|Kicker !scope="col" width=100|Kicking team !scope="col" width=100|Opponent !scope="col" width=100|Yards !scope="col" width=100|Result !scope="col" width=100|Game time !scope="col" class=unsortable|Note(s) !scope="col" class=unsortable|Reference(s) |-style="background: #BBFFBB;" |November 8, 1925 |[[George Abramson]] |[[Green Bay Packers]] |[[Chicago Cardinals]] |35 |Good |4th quarter |Game played in snow on a muddy field. | <ref>Crusinberry, James (Nov. 9, 1925). "Cards Win 9-6; Driscoll's Toe Tells Tale". ''[[Chicago Daily Tribune]]'', p. 23. Retrieved January 14, 2015.</ref> |-style="background: #BBFFBB;" |November 20, 1933 |[[Ken Strong]] |[[New York Giants]] |[[Green Bay Packers]] |30 |Good |3rd quarter | |<ref>Kelley, Robert F. (Nov. 27, 1933). "Giants turn back Green Bay by 17-6". ''[[The New York Times]]'', p. 21. Retrieved June 23, 2013.</ref> |-style="background: #FFBBBB;" |October 23, 1955 |[[Ben Agajanian]] |[[New York Giants]] |[[Pittsburgh Steelers]] |56 |Missed |2nd quarter (0:30) | |<ref>Effrat, Louis (Oct. 24, 1955). "Giants defeated by Steelers in seesaw contest at Polo Grounds". ''[[The New York Times]]'', p. 31. Retrieved June 23, 2013.</ref> |-style="background: #FFBBBB;" |November 2, 1958 |[[Gordy Soltau]] |[[San Francisco 49ers]] |[[Detroit Lions]] |61 |Missed |2nd quarter (0:15) | |<ref>"Old-timers Perry, McElhenny, Tittle star in 24-21 rally". (Nov. 3, 1958). ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'', p. c1. Retrieved June 23, 2013.</ref> |-style="background: #FFBBBB;" |September 13, 1964 |[[Sam Baker (halfback)|Sam Baker]] |[[Philadelphia Eagles]] |[[New York Giants]] |47 |Missed |2nd quarter (0:00) | |<ref>Wallace, William N. (Sep. 14, 1964). "Safetyman blitz shackles Tittle". ''[[The New York Times]]'', p. 44. {{Multiple issues|{{essay-like|date=December 2016}}
{{Orphan|date=January 2017}}}}
During the 20th century, specifically in the [[Interwar period|Interwar period,]] athletics became a point of social integration in [[Jewish communities of Europe|Jewish communities]] throughout Europe. Specifically within [[Culture of Germany|German society]], playing sports provided a chance for [[Jews]] to gain social standing and even notoriety for their accomplishments. Additionally, cheering for local area sports teams and clubs provided a common (secular) point of interest between Jews and non-Jews. While there are many instances of social integration and acceptance as a result of sports, antisemitism was common at sporting events in central Europe as well. Discrimination, provocation, and riots occurred at sporting events and in response to Jewish athletes, coaches, and managers. As such, the public perception of Jewish athletics was mixed, with notable examples of fame and antisemitism throughout the 20th century.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Emancipation Through Muscles: Jews and Sports in Europe|last=|first=|publisher=University of Nebraska Press|year=2006|isbn=0-8032-1355-7|editor-last=Brenner|editor-first=Michael|location=Lincoln, Nebraska|pages=|quote=|editor-last2=Reuveni|editor-first2=Gideon|via=}}</ref>
==Jews and sports in Germany==
An example of the success that some Jewish athletes achieved in [[Germany]] can be seen through [[Daniel Prenn]], a Russian-born tennis player who competed for the German national tennis team in the 1920s and 1930s. Through Prenn was a Russian citizen, his notable wins for Germany in the [[Davis Cup]] helped to bring him the acclaim and recognition that was primarily reserved for non-Jewish athletes in Germany. As a result of his numerous victories, Prenn was featured in an article in the ''[[Israelitisches Familienblatt]]'' (IF), a German newspaper. While the IF normally relegated articles on sporting events to the secondary sections of the publication, by 1932, sporting articles were often featured with large headlines—and even photographs of Jewish athletes—in primary sections of the newspaper. These changes were unprecedented in the IF, and provided hope that sports could become a path for Jews in Germany to reach social integration and equality.<ref name=":0">Borut, J. (2006). Jews in German Sports during the Weimar Republic. ''Emancipation through Muscles: Jews and Sports in Europe'', 77ff-87.</ref>
Additionally, as Jewish athletes such as Daniel Prenn began gaining notoriety for their accomplishments, German publications and spectators became more favorable toward them. In another German publication, ''[[Vossische Zeitung]]'', Prenn's success was well documented, with references to German spectators who began to accept Prenn as "Our Prenn" -- "Unser Prenn" in German. This acceptance of Prenn, a Jewish athlete, into German society was a large step forward for the Jewish hope to become equal and contributing members of German society.<ref name=":0" />
==Antisemitism in sports==
While Daniel Prenn had experienced the acclaim and recognition of success for the German national tennis team in multiple Davis Cup victories, he was not immune to the [[Antisemitism|hate and discrimination]] that plagued Jews in Germany. After negotiations with a local tennis racquet supplier fell through, Prenn was accused of breaking the laws of [[Amateur sports|amateurism]], and was eventually taken to court over the matter. While Prenn was found innocent of these charges, the German Tennis Association still decided to suspend Prenn for a six-month period to resolve the baseless claims. This discrimination against the Jewish Prenn came as a large blow to a younger generation of Jewish athletes in Germany who admired Prenn and his accomplishments. As a result of these allegations and the unnecessary and unwarranted suspension by the German Tennis Association, Prenn ended up leaving the German association in favor of the Jewish sports club, Berlin Bar Kochba.<ref name=":0" />
==Public perception of Jewish athletes==
Despite the success seen by many Jewish athletes in German sports competitions, hateful and derogatory comments were still common among German spectators. An example of this rabid anti-semitism occurred during a sporting competition in [[Rostock]], Germany which featured many sports clubs, including Berlin Bar Kochba, which was a primarily Jewish club. After Bar Kochba's athletes began winning many of the events at the competition, chants of "Hep Hep" were made throughout the crowd of spectators. These anti-Jewish chants (in reference to the [[Hep-Hep riots|Hep-Hep Riots]] of 1819) nearly pushed Bar Kochba to withdraw and leave the competition entirely.<ref name=":0" />
Another example of the rampant antisemitism that plagued Jewish athletes across Europe came from the soccer matches played by [[Hakoah Vienna]], a Jewish sports club in [[Austria]]. While derogatory comments were present in any soccer match, these same comments turned into antisemitic comments when Hakoah took the pitch. Comments of "Jew pig" or "dirty Jew"—translated from the German "Judensau" and "Drecksjude"—were common for Hakoah players and supporters.<ref>Bunzl, J. (2006). Hakoah Vienna: Reflections on a Legend. ''Emancipation through Muscles: Jews and Sports in Europe'', 106-115.</ref> These actions against Hakoah Vienna were not limited to hateful comments, but extended into rioting as well. In August 1923, at a match between Hakoah Vienna and [[Ostmark (Austria)|Ostmark]], the Austrian news publication ''Wiener Morgenzeitung'' reported that these riots featured verbal abuse and constant antisemitic threats levied against the "Jewish pigs" of Hakoah. While this publication focused on the riots occurring at that particular match, it made mention of the constant barrage of threats and insults thrown toward Hakoah players and supporters at every match, even at their home field in Krieau.<ref>John, M. (2006). Anti-Semitism in Austrian Sports between the Wars ‘. ''Emancipation Through Muscles: Jews and Sports in Europe, London: Nebraska''.</ref>
==Further reading== * Belda, Maciej Władysław. ''The Maccabees of Sport: Jewish Sport in Kraków''. Kraków: Historical Museum of Krakow & Stara Synagoga, 2012. {{ISBN|8375771201}}.
==References== {{reflist|30em}}

{{use dmy dates|date=March 2012}} {{Infobox stadium | name = Kilbowie Park | nickname = | image = | caption = | fullname = | former_names = | pushpin_map = Scotland West Dunbartonshire | pushpin_mapsize = 250 | pushpin_map_caption = Location in West Dunbartonshire | pushpin_label_position = left | coordinates = {{coord|55|54|5.9|N|4|24|12.9|W|type:landmark|display=inline}} | location = [[Clydebank]],
[[West Dunbartonshire]], [[Scotland]] | broke_ground = | built = | opened = 1939 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = 1996 | demolished = | owner = | operator = | surface = Grass | cost = | architect = | capacity = | record_attendance = 14,900
[[East Stirlingshire F.C.|E.S. Clydebank]] v [[Hibernian F.C.|Hibernian]]
10 February 1965 | dimensions = | acreage = | tenants = {{infobox stadium/tenantlist | tenant_clubs = [[Clydebank Juniors F.C.|Clydebank Juniors]]
[[East Stirlingshire F.C.|ES Clydebank]]
[[Clydebank F.C.|Clydebank]] | tenant_years = 1939–1964
1964–1965
1965–1996 }}| website = }} '''Kilbowie Park''', also known as '''New Kilbowie Park''', was a [[association football|football]] stadium in [[Clydebank]], [[Scotland]]. It was the home ground of [[Clydebank F.C.|Clydebank]]. New Kilbowie was built for Clydebank Juniors in 1939.{{harvnb|Inglis|1996|p=437}} In 1964, Clydebank merged with [[East Stirlingshire F.C.|East Stirlingshire]] and entered the [[Scottish Football League]]. A record attendance of 14,900 was set by a visit of [[Hibernian F.C.|Hibernian]] in February 1965. Floodlights were first used in a match against [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] in the same month. The merger collapsed after a legal battle, but Clydebank entered the league in their own right in [[1966–67 in Scottish football|1966]]. Clydebank were promoted to the [[Scottish Football League Premier Division|Premier Division]] in [[1976–77 in Scottish football|1977]]. A covered plastic-seated stand was built, which was funded by selling star player [[Davie Cooper]] for £100,000 to [[Rangers F.C.|Rangers]]. To avoid having to apply legislation affecting stadium safety, the club installed wooden benches that reduced the capacity to 9,950. This was below the 10,000 limit at which the legislation started to apply and technically made Kilbowie the first [[all-seater stadium]] in the United Kingdom. Clydebank played their last competitive game at Kilbowie against [[Hamilton Academical F.C.|Hamilton Academical]] in 1996 (1-3). The last ever game at Kilbowie was a testimonial match later that summer for [[Ken Eadie]], against Rangers (2-3). The ground was sold by club owners, the Steedman family, in 1997. Clydebank endured several seasons groundsharing at [[Cappielow]] in [[Greenock]] and [[Boghead Park]] in [[Dumbarton]].{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/scotland/2079740.stm|title=Demise of the Bankies|last=Lamont|first=Alasdair|publisher=BBC|work=[[BBC Sport]]|date=1 July 2002|accessdate=7 March 2011}} Land was purchased on Great Western Road on the outskirts of the town to construct a new stadium for the club, but the necessary approval was never obtained. The sale of Kilbowie Park was the catalyst for the club's decline, which was finally ended in 2002. The club was purchased from its administrator by Jim Ballantyne, who moved it to [[Airdrie, North Lanarkshire]] and renamed it [[Airdrie United F.C.|Airdrie United]].{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/scotland/2130445.stm|title=Well dries for the Bankies|date=15 July 2002|accessdate=6 November 2011|work=BBC Sport|publisher=BBC|first=Alasdair|last=Lamont}} This was done to replace the [[Airdrieonians F.C. (1878)|Airdrieonians]] club, which had been liquidated earlier in 2002. Clydebank F.C. was reformed as a [[Scottish Junior Football Association|junior]] club by the United Clydebank Supporters{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/scotland/2125828.stm|title=Bankies aim for junior status|date=12 July 2002|accessdate=6 November 2011|work=BBC Sport|publisher=BBC}} and it now plays at Holm Park in [[Yoker]].{{cite news|url=http://www.scotsman.com/sport/reborn_clydebank_in_junior_cup_final_seven_years_after_death_1_1040388|title=Reborn Clydebank in Junior Cup final seven years after 'death'|work=sport.scotsman.com|publisher=Johnston Press|date=29 May 2009|accessdate=6 November 2011}} Kilbowie was purchased by Vico Properties plc, who developed a retail scheme and restaurants on the ground.{{cite web|url=http://www.vicoproperties.com/developments/retail/kilbowie.html |title=Kilbowie Retail Park |work= |publisher=Vico Properties plc |accessdate=6 November 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120425142541/http://www.vicoproperties.com/developments/retail/kilbowie.html |archivedate=25 April 2012 |df= }} A single piece of rubble of the old stadium is now on view at the Scottish Football Museum in [[Hampden Park]]. ==See also== * [[History of Scottish football#Stadium moves and refurbishments|Scottish stadium moves]] ==References== {{reflist}} ; Sources *{{cite book| ref = harv | first = Simon | last = Inglis | title = Football Grounds of Britain | year = 1996 | publisher = Collins Willow | isbn = 0-00-218426-5 }} {{Clydebank F.C.}} {{Football venues in Scotland}} {{Coord|55.90383|-4.403479|display=title}} [[Category:Clydebank F.C.]] [[Category:Defunct football venues in Scotland]] [[Category:Sports venues in West Dunbartonshire]] [[Category:Scottish Football League venues]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1939]]

3 [[Chairlift|doublechair]] |snowmaking = yes |external_link=[http://www.bohinj.si/kobla/en/naprave.html/ bohinj.si/kobla] |}} '''Kobla Ski Resort''' was a Slovenian [[ski resort]] located at [[Bohinjska Bistrica]] on Kobla mountain in municipality of [[Bohinj]]. It has 23 km of ski slopes. Closest city is [[Bled]], half an hour away. ==Resort statistics== Elevation
