Base - 540 m / 1,771 ft Ski Terrain
0,9 km2 (222 acres) - covering {{convert|23|km|mi|abbr=on}} of ski slopes on one mountain. Slope Difficulty
/ Vertical Drop
- 940 m / (833 ft) in total Longest Run: 6 km Average Winter Daytime Temperature: Average Annual Snowfall: Lift Capacity: 6,000 skiers per hour (all together) Ski Season Opens: December Ski Season Ends: March Snow Conditions Phone Line: +386 0 (4) 5747100 ==Ski lifts== {| border="2" cellpadding="4" cellspacing="0" style="margin:0 1em 0 0; background: #f9f9f9; border: 1px #aaa solid; border-collapse: collapse; font-size: 95%;" |- align=center | '''Name''' | '''Length''' |- align=right |Kobla I |846m |- align=right |Kobla II |947m |- align=right |Kobla III |1360m |- align=right |Ravne |728m |- align=right |Kozji hrbet |433m |- align=right |Bistrica |367m |} ==External links== * [http://www.bohinj.si/kobla/en/naprave.html/ bohinj.si/kobla] - official site [[Category:Ski areas and resorts in Slovenia]] {{Slovenia-sports-venue-stub}}

page.title: List of Hispanic and Latino Americans

revision.text:
{{distinguish|List of Latin Americans}} {{cleanup|date=February 2010}} <!-- Only people who have biographies at Wikipedia should be included on this list, and only provided there is a [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources|reliable source]] to show that they identify with any of the above-listed groups. [[WP:FLAGCRUFT|No flags]] should accompany the names—the flags currently in the article are in process of removal. ---> <!-- PEOPLE IN THIS CATEGORY MUST BE AMERICAN/HAVE AMERICAN CITIZENSHIP. THIS IS NOT A LIST OF ALL LATINOS ---> <!-- Please do not add yourself, non-notable people or fictional characters. Please add citations where appropriate ---> {{Inc-sport}}
{{Americans}} {{Hispanic and Latino Americans|right}} {{Expand list|date=January 2011}} This is a list of notable [[Hispanic and Latino Americans]]: citizens or residents of the United States with origins in [[Hispanic America]] or Spain.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://factfinder.census.gov/home/en/epss/glossary_h.html#hispanic_or_latino_origin |title=American FactFinder Help; Hispanic or Latino origin |accessdate=2010-02-04 |publisher=U.S. Census Bureau |quote=For Census 2000, American Community Survey: People who identify with the terms "Hispanic" or "Latino" are those who classify themselves in one of the specific Hispanic or Latino categories listed on the Census 2000 or ACS questionnaire - "Mexican," "Puerto Rican," or "Cuban" - as well as those who indicate that they are "other Spanish, Hispanic, or Latino." Origin can be viewed as the heritage, nationality group, lineage, or country of birth of the person or the person's parents or ancestors before their arrival in the United States. People who identify their origin as Spanish, Hispanic, or Latino may be of any race. 1990 Census of Population and Housing: A self-designated classification for people whose origins are from Spain, the Spanish-speaking countries of Central or South America, the Caribbean, or those identifying themselves generally as Spanish, Spanish-American, etc. Origin can be viewed as ancestry, nationality, or country of birth of the person or person's parents or ancestors prior to their arrival in the United States. |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100227020050/http://factfinder.census.gov/home/en/epss/glossary_h.html |archivedate=2010-02-27 |df= }}</ref> The following groups are officially designated as "Spanish/Hispanic/Latino":<ref>{{cite web |url=http://factfinder.census.gov/home/en/epss/glossary_s.html#spanish_hispanic_latino |title=American FactFinder Help; Spanish/Hispanic/Latino |accessdate=2010-02-04 |publisher=U.S. Census Bureau |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100331235251/http://factfinder.census.gov/home/en/epss/glossary_s.html#spanish_hispanic_latino |archivedate=2010-03-31 |df= }}</ref> [[Mexican American]], [[Puerto Ricans in the United States|(Stateside) Puerto Rican]], [[Cuban American]], [[Dominican American]], [[Costa Rican American]], [[Guatemalan American]], [[Honduran American]], [[Nicaraguan American]], [[Panamanian American]], [[Salvadoran American]], [[Argentine American]], [[Bolivian American]], [[Chilean American]], [[Colombian American]], [[Ecuadorian American]], [[Paraguayan American]], [[Peruvian American]], [[Spanish American]], [[Uruguayan American]], and [[Venezuelan American]]. However, Hispanic or Latino people can have any ancestry.
==Architects== * [[Monica Ponce de Leon]] – first Hispanic architect to receive the [[National Design Award]] in Architecture from the Smithsonian; has received over 12 Progressive Architecture Awards and the Design Award Medal from the Academy of Arts and Letters; first Hispanic dean at the University of Michigan
=== Architects=== Joseph Phillip Martinez was the first Mexican-American in the 20th century to receive a Master of Architecture degree from Harvard University. He was the founding Dean at The New School of Architecture; he previously taught at UC Berkeley. His broad professional practice has garnered various awards including a National AIA Presidential Award, Normal Heights Restoration Plan, and a National AIA Citation, Cesar E. Chavez Elementary School. He was named by the National Association of Land Grant Universities and Colleges as Alumni of the Century for the University of California San Diego—only other Mexican-American honored was Henry Cisneros from Texas A&M University. He was honored with a Lifetime Achievement Award from California Rural Legal Assistance; moreover, he was honored by Barrio Station with a Lifetime Achievement Award. For more than 40 years his Eclectic Design Methodology has resulted in a portfolio of unique works of Architecture, he is the “Father of Chicano Architecture”. In addition to professional practice, he is a staff writer for ByDesign E-magazine via UC Berkeley College of Environmental Design.
==Baseball== *{{flagicon|MEX}} [[Jorge Cantú]] – MLB infielder<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/03/17/sports/sportsspecial/17usa.html | work=The New York Times | title=United States Runs Out of Chances in Classic | first=Murray | last=Chass | date=2006-03-17 | accessdate=2010-05-08}}</ref> *[[Johnny Estrada]] – MLB catcher<ref name="news.newamericamedia.org">[http://news.newamericamedia.org/news/view_article.html?article_id=3b2642696eb2ea042bf37b8cf0edbefd Santana and 'Big Papi' Lead Latino Baseballers - NAM<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131017024602/http://news.newamericamedia.org/news/view_article.html?article_id=3b2642696eb2ea042bf37b8cf0edbefd |date=2013-10-17 }}</ref> *{{flagicon|MEX}} [[Brian Fuentes]] – [[Major League Baseball|MLB]] relief pitcher, three-time All-Star<ref name="news.newamericamedia.org"/> *{{flagicon|PAN}} [[Mariano Rivera]] – MLB Closer *[[Javier Baez]] – MLB infielder
==Basketball== *{{flagicon|Uruguay}} [[Esteban Batista]] – [[National Basketball Association|NBA]] player<ref>{{cite news|url=http://asp.usatoday.com/community/utils/idmap/29003738.story |title=Richardson exporting his deep basketball knowledge - USATODAY.com |work=USA Today |first=Marlen |last=Garcia |date=2007-06-14 |accessdate=2010-05-08 }}{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
==Boxing== *{{flagicon|MEX}} [[Bobby Chacon]] – boxer<ref>{{cite web| last =Sanderson| first =Matthew| title =Class of '05 Controversy| work =TigerBoxing.com| date =2005-01-20| url =http://www.tigerboxing.com/articles/index.php?aid=1001244866| accessdate =2007-07-18}}</ref> *{{flagicon|MEX}} [[Delia Gonzalez]] – boxer<ref>{{cite web|last=Santiago |first=Antonio |title=A Chiquita with a Big Heart |work=RingsideReport.com |date=2006-04-13 |url=http://www.ringsidereport.com/Santiago04132006.htm |accessdate=2007-07-18 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927202522/http://www.ringsidereport.com/Santiago04132006.htm |archivedate=2007-09-27 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> *{{flagicon|El Salvador}} [[Carlos Hernández (boxer)|Carlos Hernández]] – boxer *{{flagicon|MEX}} [[Sergio Mora]] – boxer <ref>{{cite web| last =Bjornberg| first =Jeremy| title =Sergio Mora No Longer a Contender?| work =Doc's Sport Service| date =2005-12-02| url =http://www.docsports.com/boxing/sergio-mora-1.html| accessdate =2007-07-18}}</ref>
== Football == *[[Raul Allegre]] – [[National Football League|NFL]] placekicker<ref name="AZ">{{cite web| last =Somers| first =Ken | title =NFL looks for big play in Mexico| work =[[Arizona Republic]]| date =2005-09-25| url =http://www.azcentral.com/arizonarepublic/sports/articles/0925nfllatin0925.html| accessdate =2007-07-18}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> *[[Leo Barker]] – retired NFL linebacker<ref name="AZ"/> *[[Tony Casillas]] – retired NFL defensive lineman<ref name="AZ"/> *{{flagicon|MEX}}[[Joe Kapp]] – retired NFL quarterback<ref name="AZ"/> *{{flagicon|MEX}} [[J. P. Losman]] – NFL quarterback<ref>{{cite news| last =Brady| first =Erik| title =Losman growing at his own beat| work =[[USA TODAY]]| date =2005-07-20| url =https://www.usatoday.com/sports/football/nfl/bills/2005-07-20-losman-cover_x.htm| accessdate =2007-07-18}}</ref> *[[Max Montoya]] – retired NFL guard<ref name="AZ"/> *[[Zeke Moreno]] – former NFL linebacker<ref>{{cite web|title=In The Zone with San Diego Chargers Linebacker Zeke Moreno |work=[[Open Your Eyes (magazine)|Open Your Eyes]] |url=http://www.oyemag.com/zeke.html |accessdate=2007-07-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070804173755/http://www.oyemag.com/zeke.html |archivedate=2007-08-04 |df= }}</ref> *{{flagicon|MEX}} [[Anthony Muñoz]] – retired NFL offensive guard, member of [[Pro Football Hall of Fame]] <ref name="AZ"/>
==Gymnasts== *{{flagicon|Puerto Rico}} [[John Orozco]] – bronze medal gymnast *{{flagicon|Puerto Rico}} [[Laurie Hernandez]] – American artistic gymnast
==Martial artists== *{{flagicon|MEX}} [[Nick Diaz]] – [[Ultimate Fighting Championship|UFC]] / [[mixed martial arts]]<ref name="BR">{{cite web|last=Probst |first=Jason |author2=DiSanto, Michael |title=Head-2-Head: Sanchez vs. Diaz |work=Between Rounds |publisher=InsideFighting.com |date=2005-11-02 |url=http://www.insidefighting.com/betweenRoundsDisp.aspx?uid=2430 |accessdate=2007-07-18 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927190821/http://www.insidefighting.com/betweenRoundsDisp.aspx?uid=2430 |archivedate=2007-09-27 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
==Soccer== *{{flagicon|MEX}} [[Ivan Becerra]] – soccer forward for [[Columbus Crew]]<ref>{{cite web| title =Crew Selects Three Players In 2006 MLS Supplemental Draft| work =OurSportsCentral.com| date =2006-01-26| url =http://www.oursportscentral.com/services/releases/?id=3263065| accessdate =2007-07-18}} "He was born in San Luis Potose, Mexico, becoming the first Mexican-born player drafted by The Crew. His full name is Jorge Ivan Becerra."</ref> *{{flagicon|MEX}} [[Carlos Bocanegra]] – footballer who plays for [[Rangers F.C.|Rangers]]<ref>{{cite web| last =Wyllie| first =John Philip| title =Rimando and Bocanegra Vie for World Cup Berths| work =La Prensa San Diego| date =2001-12-14| url =http://www.laprensa-sandiego.org/archieve/december14/CUP.HTM| accessdate =2007-07-18}}</ref>
== Politics ==
[[File:Tom Perez (cropped).jpg|thumb|120px|Thomas Perez]] [[File:Adriano-Espaillat.jpg|right|thumb|120px|Adriano Espaillat]] * [[Blanca Alvarado]] – politician, served on City Council and Board of Supervisors for [[San Jose, California]] * [[Alex Blanco]] – politician, mayor of [[Passaic, New Jersey]] * [[Fernando Cabrera (politician)|Fernando Cabrera]] – New York City Council member * [[Nelson Castro (politician)|Nelson Castro]] – politician from the state of New York * [[Lorraine Cortés-Vázquez]] – 65th Secretary of State of New York, serving in the Cabinet of Governor David Paterson * [[Marcos Devers]] – member of the Massachusetts House of Representatives<ref>[http://www.danr.org/ip.asp?op=press081106]{{dead link|date=April 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> * [[Grace Diaz]] – politician, Democratic State Representative from Rhode Island representing District 11 in the city of Providence, Rhode Island * [[Adriano Espaillat]] – member of the United States House of Representatives * [[Rafael Espinal]] – politician who won the open 54th district seat in the New York State Assembly in a special election held on September 13, 2011 * [[Julissa Ferreras]] – Democratic member of the New York City Council * [[Frances Garcia]] – former mayor of Hutchinson, Kansas * [[Norma García]] – former mayor of Mercedes, Texas and Hidalgo County treasurer * [[William Lantigua]] – politician in Massachusetts, Dominican born and raised<ref name="cityoflawrence.com">{{Cite web |url=http://www.cityoflawrence.com/mayor-lantigua-biography.aspx |title=Archived copy |access-date=2017-05-11 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131019133947/http://www.cityoflawrence.com/mayor-lantigua-biography.aspx |archive-date=2013-10-19 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> * [[Guillermo Linares]] – Dominican Democratic member of the New York State Assembly<ref name="nyt">{{citation|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/04/07/nyregion/07lives.html?_r=1|title=An Immigrant Success Wants Others to Have a Chance|first=Robin|last=Finn|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=April 7, 2006|accessdate=February 10, 2010}}</ref> * [[Miguel Martinez (politician)|Miguel Martinez]] – former New York City Council member from Council District 10 in Upper Manhattan in New York City * [[Joseline Peña-Melnyk]] – politician, represents District 21 in the Maryland House of Delegates *[[Geovanny Vicente|Geovanny Vicente Romero]] – Hispanic political analyst, Professor and international consultant based in Washington, D.C. * [[Cesar A. Perales]] – Secretary of State of New York currently serving in the Cabinet of Governor Andrew Cuomo * [[Thomas Perez]] – [[Democratic National Committee]] Chairman, [[United States Department of Justice Civil Rights Division|Assistant Attorney General for Civil Rights]], [[United States Secretary of Labor|US Secretary of Labor]]-designate; parents are Dominicans<ref>{{cite web | url =http://danr.org/tag/thomas-e-perez/ | title =DANR President Attends Installation Ceremony of Thomas E. Perez as US Assistant Attorney General | author =Dominican American National Roundtable | publisher =danr.org | date =November 14, 2009 | deadurl =yes | archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20140109045259/http://danr.org/tag/thomas-e-perez/ | archivedate =January 9, 2014 | df = }}</ref> * [[Ydanis Rodríguez]] – currently a Democratic New York City Council member from the borough of Manhattan * [[Angel Taveras]] – lawyer and mayor of Providence, Rhode Island; of Dominican descent; first Hispanic mayor of the city<ref name="Smith">{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Michelle R.|title=New Providence Mayor Angel Taveras sworn in|agency=Associated Press|newspaper=The Boston Globe|date=January 3, 2011|url=http://www.boston.com/news/local/rhode_island/articles/2011/01/03/new_providence_mayor_taveras_to_be_inaugurated/|accessdate=January 3, 2011}}</ref> *Carmen J Piñeyro – only Dominican elected official in Long Island. She is currently a Democratic Trustee in the Village of Freeport, New York.
==Models== *{{flagicon|Puerto Rico}} [[Melanie Iglesias]] *{{flagicon|Colombia}} [[Sofia Vergara]]
==Musicians== *{{flagicon|MEX}}/{{flagicon|USA}}[[Baby Bash]] – rapper of Mexican and Anglo descent *{{flagicon|MEX}}/{{flagicon|USA}}[[Becky G]] – rapper and singer of Mexican American descent *{{flagicon|Cuba}}/{{flagicon|USA}}[[Gloria Estefan]] – Cuban-American singer *{{flagicon|Uruguay}}/{{flagicon|USA}}[[Miguel del Aguila]] – Uruguayan American multiple Grammy nominated composer *{{flagicon|MEX}}/{{flagicon|USA}}[[Kap G]] – hardcore rapper who performs trap music *{{flagicon|Cuba}}/{{flagicon|USA}}[[José Antonio Bowen]] – [[Cuban American]] jazz musician and president of [[Goucher College]] *{{flagicon|Puerto Rico}}/{{flagicon|USA}}[[Jennifer Lopez]] – international Puerto Rican singer *{{flagicon|Puerto Rico}}/{{flagicon|USA}}[[Marc Anthony]] - Latin American singer, most recently featured with [[Bad Bunny]] in [[Will Smith]]'s new song "Esta Rico" *{{flagicon|Puerto Rico}}/{{flagicon|Dominican Republic}}/{{flagicon|USA}}[[Nicky Jam]] – Puerto Rican-Dominican singer-songwriter *{{flagicon|Cuba}}/{{flagicon|USA}}[[Pitbull (rapper)|Pitbull]] – [[Cuban American]] hip hop musician from [[Miami, Florida]] *{{flagicon|Dominican Republic}}/{{flagicon|USA}}[[Prince Royce]] – Latin R&B singer born to Dominican parents *{{flagicon|MEX}}/{{flagicon|USA}}[[Selena]] (1971–1995) – Tejano singer *{{flagicon|Colombia}}[[Shakira]] – singer, known for single "[[Hips Don't Lie]]," which reached number 1 on the American [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] and across the world; other singles include "[[Whenever, Wherever]]," "[[She Wolf (Shakira song)|She Wolf]]," and "[[Waka Waka (This Time for Africa)]]" *{{flagicon|Cuba}}/{{flagicon|USA}}[[Lauren Jauregui]] – Cuban-American pop singer *{{flagicon|Cuba}}/{{flagicon|MEX}}/{{flagicon|USA}}[[Camila Cabello]] – Mexican-Cuban-American pop singer *{{flagicon|MEX}}/{{flagicon|USA}}[[Ally Brooke]] – Mexican American pop singer
==Scientists== *[[Martha E. Bernal]] (1931–2001), Mexican-American clinical psychologist, first Latina to receive a psychology PhD in the United States *[[Antonia Novello]] (b. 1944), Puerto Rican physician, 14th Surgeon General of the United States, first woman and first Hispanic to hold the position *[[Sarah Stewart (cancer researcher)|Sarah Stewart]] (1905–1976), Mexican-American microbiologist; discovered the Polyomavirus *[[Helen Rodríguez Trías]] (1929–2001), Puerto Rican American pediatrician, advocate for women's reproductive rights *[[Melba J. T. Vasquez]] (b. 1951), counseling psychologist and first Latina president of the [[American Psychological Association]] *[[Lydia Villa-Komaroff]] (b. 1947), Mexican-American cellular biologist; third Mexican American woman in the United States to receive a PhD in the sciences *[[Rodolfo Llinás|Rodolfo Llinas]] (b. 1934) Colombian American neuroscientist.
==Writers== *[[Miguel Algarín]] (b. 1941) – Puerto Rican author and co-founder of the [[Nuyorican Poets Café]] *[[Rudolfo Anaya]] (b. 1937) – Mexican-American author of ''Bless Me, Ultima'' *[[Sandra Cisneros]] (b. 1954) – Mexican-American author of ''[[The House on Mango Street]]'' *[[Judith Ortiz Cofer]] (b. 1952) – Puerto Rican author of ''Silent Dancing: A Partial Remembrance of a Puerto Rican Childhood'' *[[Angie Cruz]] (b. 1972) – Dominican-American author of ''Let It Rain Coffee'' *[[Nelson Denis]] (b. 1954) – Puerto Rican author of ''War Against All Puerto Ricans'' and former New York State Assemblyman *[[Alberto Rios]] (b. 1952) – Mexican-American poet, Arizona's first poet first state poet laureate *[[Benjamin Alire Sáenz]] (b. 1954) – Mexican-American author of ''Everything Begins and Ends at the Kentucky Club'' *[[Sergio Troncoso]] (b. 1961) – Mexican-American author of ''The Last Tortilla and Other Stories'' and ''[[Crossing Borders: Personal Essays]]''
==See also== *[[List of Argentine Americans]] *[[List of Bolivian Americans]] *[[List of Colombian Americans]] *[[List of Cuban Americans]] *[[List of Mexican Americans]] *[[List of Nicaraguan Americans]] *[[List of Salvadoran Americans]] *[[List of Venezuelan Americans]] *[[List of Spanish Americans]] *[[List of Stateside Puerto Ricans]] *[[History of Mexican-Americans]] *[[List of Hispanic Medal of Honor recipients]] *[[Hispanic Admirals in the United States Navy]] *[[Hispanics in the United States Air Force]] *[[Hispanics in the United States Coast Guard]] *[[Hispanics in the United States Marine Corps]] *[[Hispanics in the United States Navy]] *[[Hispanics in the American Civil War]] *[[:Category:Hispanic and Latino American writers|Hispanic American writers]] *[[List of Hispanic and Latin American Britons]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Hispanic And Latino Americans, List Of}} [[Category:Hispanic and Latino American people|!]] [[Category:Lists of American people by ethnic or national origin]] [[Category:Lists of American people of Latin American descent|*]] [[Category:Lists of people by ethnicity|Hispanic]]

{{Dynamic list}} [[file:Happy Valley Racecourse 1.jpg|thumb|Happy Valley Racecourse, Hongkong, 2008]] [[file:1997-11-7-60th-kikkasyou.JPG|thumb|Racecourse in Kyoto, Japan, 1997]] [[file:Moscow Hippodrome.JPG|thumb|Hippodrom Moscow, 2007]] [[file:Bundesarchiv Bild 102-11190, St. Moritz, Winter-Rennbahn.jpg|thumb|Winter-Rennbahn St. Moritz, 1931]] [[file:Château de Pompadour - 1.jpg|thumb|Hippodrome d'Arnac-Pompadour, France, 2008]] [[file:2012 Derby crowd.jpg|thumb|Churchill Downs, Kentucky, 2007]] [[file:Hipódromo da Gávea 01.jpg|thumb|Jockey Club Brasileiro, Hipódromo da Gávea, Rio de Janeiro, 2010]] [[file:Horse Racing at the Royal Bangkok Sport Club RBSC - panoramio.jpg|thumb|Royal Bangkok Sport Club, Thailand 2008]] [[file:Spectators at Ellerslie Racecourse, 1908.jpg|thumb|Ellerslie Racecourse, New Zealand, 1908]]
This is a list of currently active '''[[horse racing]]''' venues ([[Thoroughbred racing]] and [[harness racing]]), sorted by country. In most English-speaking countries they are called "racecourses"; the United States and Anglophone Canada use "racetracks". In many non-English speaking countries the term used is "[[hippodrome]]".
==Antigua== *[[Cassada Gardens Race Track]], [[St. John's, Antigua and Barbuda|St Johns]]
==Argentina== * [[Hipodromo 27 de Abril]], [[Santiago del Estero]], [[Santiago del Estero Provience]] * [[Hipodromo Argentino de Palermo]], [[Buenos Aires]] <ref>[http://www.palermo.com.ar Hipodromo Argentino de Palermo]</ref> * [[Hipodromo Cordoba]], [[Cordoba, Argentina|Cordoba]], [[Córdoba Province, Argentina|Córdoba Province]] * [[Hipodromo de La Plata]], [[La Plata]], [[Buenos Aires Province]] * [[Hipodromo de Rosario]], [[Rosario, Santa Fe|Rosario]], [[Santa Fe Province]] * [[Hipodromo de San Isidro]], [[San Isidro, Buenos Aires|San Isidro]], Buenos Aires Province * [[Hipodromo de Tucuman]], [[San Miguel de Tucaman]], [[Tucaman Province]]
==Australia== There are over 360 registered racecourses in Australia where Thoroughbred racing takes place during about 3,050 race meetings. There are also a number of separate harness racing tracks.
===Thoroughbred Racing=== * Albury Racing club, [[Albury]], [[New South Wales]] * Armidale Jockey Club, [[Armidale, New South Wales]] <ref>[https://www.punters.com.au/tracks/Armidale_127/ Armidale Jockey Club]</ref> * [[Ascot Racecourse, Western Australia|Ascot Racecourse]], [[Perth, Western Australia]] * Bairnsdale Racecourse, [[Bairnsdale, Victoria]] * [[Ballarat Turf Club]], [[Ballarat]], [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] * Balnarring Racecourse, [[Balnarring]], Victoria * [[Belmont Park Racecourse]], Perth, Western Australia * [[Bendigo Racecourse]], [[Bendigo]], Victoria * [[Callaghan Park]], [[Rockhampton]], [[Queensland]] * [[Camperdown Racecourse]], [[Camperdown, Victoria]] * [[Canterbury Park Racecourse]], [[Sydney]], [[New South Wales]] * [[Caulfield Racecourse]], [[Melbourne]], Victoria * [[Clare Valley Racecourse]], [[Clare, South Australia]] * [[Clifford Park Racecourse]], [[Toowoomba]], [[Queensland]] * [[Cluden Racecourse]], [[Townsville]], Queensland * ==Great Britain==
{{main article|List of British racecourses}}
The United Kingdom does not have a country-wide organising body for horseracing. The remit of the [[British Horseracing Authority]] does not extend to the island of Ireland; as a result, the [[#Ireland|two tracks]] in [[Northern Ireland]] are under the jurisdiction of [[Horse Racing Ireland]].

{{unreferenced|date=April 2018}} {{Infobox cricket ground | ground_name = Lord Buddha International Cricket Stadium | nickname = Lord Buddha Stadium | native_name = गौतम बुद्ध अन्तर्राष्ट्रिय क्रिकेट रंगशाला | native_name_lang = ne | image = | caption = | country = Nepal | location = [[Nepal]] |coordinates ={{Coord|27|49|41|N|85|17|25|E|display=it}} | establishment = 2018 | seating_capacity = 40,000+ | owner = [[Dhurmus Suntali Foundation]] | operator = [[Dhurmus Suntali Foundation]] | tenants = [[Nepal national cricket team]]
[[Nepal national under-19 cricket team]] | end1 = - End | end2 = - End | international = false | firsttestdate = | firsttestyear = | firsttesthome = | firsttestaway = | lasttestdate = | lasttestyear = | lasttesthome = | lasttestaway = | firstodidate = | firstodiyear = | firstodihome = | firstodiaway = | lastodidate = | lastodiyear = | lastodihome = | lastodiaway = | year1 = - | club1 = [[Nepal cricket team]] | date = | year = | source = }} '''Lord Buddha International Cricket Ground''' or '''Gautam Buddha Cricket Ground''' or '''Gautam Buddha Stadium''' is a [[cricket]] ground which was planned to be built at Godawari, Lalitpur or at Chitawan. The campaign for the stadium was started by Sitaram Kattel / Dhurmus. The stadium is expected to be constructed within 2 and half years. Still it is not fixed where stadium will be built. {{unreferenced|date=November 2016}} {{Infobox football club | clubname = MS Tamya | image = | fullname = Markaz Shabab Tamya
نادي مركز شباب طامية | nickname = | short name = MST | founded = | ground = Damu Sport City Stadium | capacity = | chairman = Abdel Wahab Abdel Zaher | manager = Kotb Ahmed | league = [[Egyptian Second Division]] | season = [[2015–16 Egyptian Second Division|2015–16]] | position = Second Division, 4th (Group B) | website = }} '''MS Tamya''' ({{lang-ar|نادي مركز شباب طامية}}), also known as '''Tamya Youth Center''', or simply '''Tamya YC''', is an [[Egypt]]ian football club based in [[Tamiya, Egypt|Tamya]], [[Faiyum Governorate|Fayoum]], Egypt. The club is currently playing in the [[Egyptian Second Division]], the second-highest league in the [[Egyptian football league system]]. {{Egyptian Second Division}} [[Category:Egyptian Second Division]] [[Category:Football clubs in Egypt]] {{Egypt-footyclub-stub}}

===May 31, 2011 (Tuesday)=== ====[[Basketball]]==== *[[2011 FIBA Asia Champions Cup|FIBA Asia Champions Cup]] in [[PhilSports Complex|Pasig]], [[Philippines]]: (teams in '''bold''' advance to the quarterfinals) **[[2011 FIBA Asia Champions Cup#Group A|Group A]]: ***[[Westports KL Dragons|KL Dragons]] {{flagicon|MAS}} 77–101 {{flagicon|JOR}} '''[[Applied Science University (basketball team)|ASU Sports]]''' ***'''[[Smart Gilas]]''' {{flagicon|PHL}} 74–64 {{flagicon|IRQ}} '''[[Duhok SC|Duhok Sports Club]]''' ****Standings: Smart Gilas, ASU Sports 6 points (3 matches), Duhok Sports Club 5 (4), {{flagicon|KSA}} [[Ittihad FC#Today|Al-Ittihad Jeddah]] 4 (3), KL Dragons 3 (3). **[[2011 FIBA Asia Champions Cup#Group B|Group B]]: ***'''[[Al-Jalaa Aleppo]]''' {{flagicon|SYR}} 93–63 {{flagicon|UAE}} [[Al Shabab Al Arabi Club|Al Shabab]] ***'''[[Al Rayyan Sports Club|Al-Rayyan]]''' {{flagicon|QAT}} 73–78 ([[Overtime (sports)#Basketball|OT]]) {{flagicon|LBN}} '''[[Sporting Al Riyadi Beirut|Al-Riyadi Beirut]]''' ****Standings: Al-Riyadi Beirut 6 points (3 matches), {{flagicon|IRN}} '''[[Mahram Tehran BC|Mahram Tehran]]''', Al-Rayyan Sports 5 (3), Al-Jalaa Aleppo 4 (3), Al-Shabab Club 4 (4). *{{flagicon|USA}} [[2011 NBA Finals|NBA Finals]] (best-of-7 series): **[[2011 NBA Finals#Game 1|Game 1]] in [[American Airlines Arena|Miami]]: [[2010–11 Miami Heat season|Miami Heat]] 92, [[2010–11 Dallas Mavericks season|Dallas Mavericks]] 84. ''Heat lead series 1–0.'' ====[[Ice hockey]]==== *The [[National Hockey League|NHL's]] [[Atlanta Thrashers]] have been sold to [[True North Sports and Entertainment|a Winnipeg-based group]] that will move the team to [[Winnipeg Jets|that city]] for the [[2011–12 NHL season|2011–12 season]]. The league's owners are expected to ratify the deal at their next scheduled meeting on June 21. The move brings the NHL back to [[Winnipeg]] for the first time since the [[Winnipeg Jets (1972–96)|Jets]] left for [[Phoenix Coyotes|Phoenix]] in [[1996–97 NHL season|1996]], and also makes [[Atlanta]] the first city to lose two NHL teams in the league's modern era.{{cite news|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nhl/news/story?id=6610414 |title=Thrashers headed to Winnipeg |work=[[ESPN.com]] |date=May 31, 2011 |accessdate=June 1, 2011}} ====[[Tennis]]==== *[[2011 French Open|French Open]] in [[Stade Roland Garros|Paris]], [[France]], [[2011 French Open#Day 10 (May 31)|day 10]]: **[[2011 French Open – Men's Singles|Men's Singles]]: ***Fourth round: '''[[Andy Murray]]''' {{cc3|GBR}} [4] def. [[Viktor Troicki]] {{cc3|SRB}} [15] 4–6, 4–6, 6–3, 6–2, 7–5 ***[[2011 French Open – Men's Singles#Finals|Quarterfinals]]: ****'''[[Novak Djokovic]]''' {{cc3|SRB}} [2] def. [[Fabio Fognini]] {{cc3|ITA}} [[walkover]] ****'''[[Roger Federer]]''' {{cc3|SUI}} [3] def. [[Gaël Monfils]] {{cc3|FRA}} [9] 6–4, 6–3, 7–6(3) **[[2011 French Open – Women's Singles#Finals|Women's Singles Quarterfinals]]: ***'''[[Francesca Schiavone]]''' {{cc3|ITA}} [5] def. [[Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova]] {{cc3|RUS}} [14] 1–6, 7–5, 7–5 ***'''[[Marion Bartoli]]''' {{cc3|FRA}} [11] def. [[Svetlana Kuznetsova]] {{cc3|RUS}} [13] 7–6(4), 6–4
===May 30, 2011 (Monday)=== ====[[Basketball]]==== *[[2011 FIBA Asia Champions Cup|FIBA Asia Champions Cup]] in [[PhilSports Complex|Pasig]], [[Philippines]]: (teams in '''bold''' advance to the quarterfinals) **[[2011 FIBA Asia Champions Cup#Group A|Group A]]: ***'''[[Applied Science University (basketball team)|ASU Sports]]''' {{flagicon|JOR}} 79–69 {{flagicon|KSA}} [[Ittihad FC#Today|Al-Ittihad Jeddah]] ***[[Duhok SC|Duhok Sports Club]] {{flagicon|IRQ}} 88–76 {{flagicon|MAS}} [[Westports KL Dragons|KL Dragons]] ****Standings: {{flagicon|PHL}} '''[[Smart Gilas]]''', ASU Sports 4 points (2 matches), Al-Ittihad Jeddah, Duhok Sports Club 4 (3), KL Dragons 2 (2). **[[2011 FIBA Asia Champions Cup#Group B|Group B]]: ***'''[[Sporting Al Riyadi Beirut|Al-Riyadi Beirut]]''' {{flagicon|LBN}} 76–73 {{flagicon|IRN}} '''[[Mahram Tehran BC|Mahram Tehran]]''' ***[[Al Shabab Al Arabi Club|Al Shabab]] {{flagicon|UAE}} 60–78 {{flagicon|QAT}} '''[[Al Rayyan Sports Club|Al-Rayyan]]''' ****Standings: Mahram Tehran 5 points (3 matches), Al-Rayyan Sports, Al-Riyadi Beirut 4 (2), Al-Shabab Club 3 (3), {{flagicon|SYR}} [[Al-Jalaa Aleppo]] 2 (2). ====[[Cricket]]==== *[[Sri Lankan cricket team in England in 2011|Sri Lanka in England]]: **[[Sri Lankan cricket team in England in 2011#1st Test|1st Test]] in [[SWALEC Stadium|Cardiff]]; day 5: {{cr|SRI}} 400 & 82 (24.4 overs); {{cr|ENG}} 496/5[[Declaration and forfeiture#Declaration|d]] (155 overs; [[Ian Bell]] 103[[not out|*]]). '''Pakistan win by 5 wickets; win 2-match series 2–0.''' ====[[Association football|Football (soccer)]]==== *[[2011 UEFA Women's U-19 Championship|UEFA Women's U-19 Championship]] in [[Italy]]: **[[2011 UEFA Women's U-19 Championship#Group A|Group A]]: ***{{fbw-rt|ITA}} 2–1 {{fbw|RUS}} in [[Imola]] ***{{fbw-rt|SUI}} 4–1 {{fbw|BEL}} in [[Bellaria – Igea Marina|Bellaria]] **[[2011 UEFA Women's U-19 Championship#Group B|Group B]]: ***{{fbw-rt|GER}} 3–1 {{fbw|NOR}} in [[Cervia]] ***{{fbw-rt|ESP}} 1–1 {{fbw|NED}} in [[Forlì]] ====[[Motorcycle racing]]==== *[[2011 Superbike World Championship season|Superbike]]: **[[2011 Miller Superbike World Championship round|Miller World Championship round]] in [[Miller Motorsports Park|Tooele, Utah]], [[United States]]: ***Race 1: (1) [[Carlos Checa]] {{cc3|ESP}} ([[Ducati 1198]]) (2) [[Jakub Smrž]] {{cc3|CZE}} (Ducati 1198) (3) [[Sylvain Guintoli]] {{cc3|FRA}} (Ducati 1198) ***Race 2: (1) Checa (2) [[Leon Camier]] {{cc3|GBR}} ([[Aprilia RSV4]]) (3) [[Max Biaggi]] {{cc3|ITA}} (Aprilia RSV4) ****Riders' championship standings (after 5 of 13 rounds): (1) Checa 195 points (2) [[Marco Melandri]] {{cc3|ITA}} ([[Yamaha YZF-R1]]) 134 (3) Biaggi 133 ====[[Tennis]]==== *[[2011 French Open|French Open]] in [[Stade Roland Garros|Paris]], [[France]], [[2011 French Open#Day 9 (May 30)|day 9]]: **[[2011 French Open – Men's Singles|Men's Singles]], fourth round: ***'''[[Rafael Nadal]]''' {{cc3|ESP}} [1] def. {{About|the village in Mauritius}} {{Infobox settlement | name = Moka | settlement_type = Village | imagemap = File:Mauritius-Moka.png | mapsize = 100px | map_caption = [[Moka District]] | pushpin_map = Mauritius | pushpin_label_position = right | pushpin_mapsize = 200px | pushpin_map_caption = Moka's location in Mauritius | coordinates = {{coord|20.219|S|57.496|E|format=dec|display=inline,title}} | subdivision_type = Country | subdivision_name = [[Mauritius]] | subdivision_type1 = Districts | subdivision_name1 = [[Moka District]] | established_title = | established_date = | founder = | named_for = | area_total_km2 = | elevation_footnotes = {{cite web |url = http://www.chinci.com/travel/pax/q/934274/River+Moka/MU/Mauritius/0/#1%7C0%7Ctravel%7Cpax%7C0%7C934277%7CMoka%7CMU%7CMauritius%7CIndian/Mauritius%7CMU.15%7CPPL%7C-20.2188889%7C57.4958333%7CMoka|title = Quick info, Local Time in Moka, Moka, Mauritius |publisher = Chinchi.com }} | elevation_m = 203 | elevation_ft = 666 | elevation_max_footnotes = {{cite web|url=http://www.wolframalpha.com/entities/cities_elevation/what_is_the_elevation_of_moka,_mauritius%3F/k7/9p/yd/|title=What is the elevation of Moka, Mauritius?|publisher=WolframAlpha}} | elevation_max_m = 425 | elevation_max_ft = 1394 | population_footnotes = | population_total = 8,846 | population_as_of = October 2011 | population_density_km2 = 507.2 | population_demonym = | timezone1 = [[Mauritius Time]] | utc_offset1 = +4 | blank_name = [[Köppen climate classification|Climate]] | blank_info = [[Tropical monsoon climate|Am]] | area_code = 230 | iso_code = MU }} '''Moka''' ([[Mauritian Creole|Creole]] pronunciation: [[Mauritian Creole phonology|[moka]]]) is a village in [[Mauritius]] located in the [[Moka District]], the western part of the village also lies in the [[Plaines Wilhems District]].{{cite journal|url=http://www.gov.mu/portal/goc/cso/report/census11v1/volum1.pdf|publisher=Government of Mauritius|title=Housing and population Census 2011|author=[[Statistics Mauritius]]|year=2011|accessdate=28 November 2012}} The village is administered by the Moka Village Council under the aegis of the Moka District Council.{{cite journal|url=http://www.gov.mu/portal/goc/mlge/files/lga2011.pdf|publisher=Government of Mauritius|title=Local Government Act 2011|author=Ministry of Local Government and Outer Islands|accessdate=28 November 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121114132142/http://www.gov.mu/portal/goc/mlge/files/lga2011.pdf|archivedate=14 November 2012|df=}} According to the census made by [[Statistics Mauritius]] in 2011, the population was at 8,846.{{cite journal| url= http://www.gov.mu/portal/goc/cso/report2013/migra2012.pdf| publisher= Central Statistic Office| title= Table G1 - Resident population by geographical location, whereabouts on census night and sex| page= 3| year= 2011| accessdate= 2012-11-29| deadurl= yes| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20160303184757/http://www.gov.mu/portal/goc/cso/report2013/migra2012.pdf| archivedate= 2016-03-03| df= }} The elevation is 203 meters and can be up to 425 meters in some places. Moka is directly on the other side of the [[Moka Range]] from [[Port Louis]]. The village is close to the mountain [[Le Pouce]] and the town [[Beau-Bassin Rose-Hill]]. Réduit is a suburb of the village where the [[State House (Mauritius)|State House]] and [[University of Mauritius]] is situated. The village is also home to the [[Mauritius Broadcasting Corporation]] and the Mahatma Gandhi Institute. ==History== ===Housing boom=== Moka is centrally located in Mauritius and as such has experienced a real estate development boom in the past few years. This was mainly encouraged by the development of the CyberCity two kilometers away in [[Ebene City|Ebene]]. Another contributing factor to this property business was the fact that since Mauritius will not benefit from preferential prices for its sugar by the European Community and [[World Trade Organization]], sugar estates quickly started real estate business units that would convert the land under sugar cane culture to residential lands. From 2004 to 2006, Moka saw five property estate developments. ==Weather== Moka has a [[Tropical monsoon climate|tropical wet climate]]. Since it is in the [[southern hemisphere]], February is the warmest month and August is the coolest. Temperatures normally can range from {{convert|82|F|C|order=flip}} in February to {{convert|59|F|C|order=flip}} at night in August. The dry season is in October, the wet season is in February. Temperature is somewhat constant. ==Places== ===Schools=== Schools in Moka include [[Le Bocage International School]],"[http://www.lebocage.net/ Home]." [[Le Bocage International School]]. Retrieved on May 4, 2015. Mahatama Gandhi Institute, Mahatma Gandhi Secondary School, St. Mary Roman Catholic School,{{fact|date=May 2015}} and Ecole du Centre."[http://www.aefe.fr/reseau-scolaire-mondial/rechercher-un-etablissement/maurice-mapou-ecole-du-nord École du Nord]." [[AEFE]]. Retrieved on May 4, 2015. '''University''' [[University of Mauritius]]
[[Charles Telfair Institute]] [[File:Cropped-cropped-image-campus-final.jpg|thumb|276x276px]] ===Other=== Other important institutions in Moka are the: * Agricultural Marketing Board (AMB) which stocks vegetables (mainly potatoes) for local consumption * Subramaniam Bharati Eye Centre (AKA Moka Eye Hospital) which is the country's only specialized eye hospital. * Catholic Church ==Notable people== *[[Thomas Shadrach James]], Australian pioneer == See also == * [[List of places in Mauritius]] == References == {{Commonscat}} {{reflist}} [[Category:Moka District]] [[Category:Populated places in Mauritius]] {{Mauritius-sport-stub}}

{{Infobox stadium | name = Mokdong Stadium | nickname = [[Image:Mokdong Stadium3.JPG|250px]] | location = 914 Mok-dong, [[Yangcheon-gu]], [[Seoul]], South Korea | broke_ground = 19 December 1987 | opened = 14 November 1989 | operator = Seoul Facilities Management Corporation | construction_cost = 8.5 billion [[South Korean won|won]] | architect = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names = | tenants = [[Jeju United FC|Bucheon SK]] (1996–2000)
[[FC Seoul|Anyang LG Cheetahs]] (2001) | capacity = 20,236 }} '''Mokdong Stadium''' ({{ko-hhrm|hangul= 목동주경기장 |hanja = 木洞運動場}}) is a [[sports complex]] located in [[Mok-dong]], [[Yangcheon-gu]], [[Seoul]]. It consists of [[multi-purpose stadium]], a [[baseball stadium]], and an [[Ice rink|Artificial ice rink]]. It was opened on November 14, 1989. The main stadium hosted [[K League]] football matches from 1993 to 2001. == Facilities == === Mokdong Stadium === It is multi-purpose stadium and currently used mostly for football and athletics and was the home stadium of [[Jeju United FC|Bucheon SK]] (Currently Jeju United FC) before they were moved to [[Bucheon]]. The stadium holds 20,236 people and opened in 1989. === Mokdong Baseball Stadium === * ''For details, see [[Mokdong Baseball Stadium]].'' === Mokdong Ice Rink === * Mokdong Ice Rink – it was used as the filming location for [[Seoul Broadcasting System|Seoul Broadcasting System (SBS)]]'s drama ''[[Lovers in Paris]]'', where Ki-joo, played by [[Park Shin-yang]], and Soo-hyuk, played by [[Lee Dong-gun]], played ice hockey.{{cite web|title=Korean TV Drama: ''Lovers in Paris''|url=http://english.visitkorea.or.kr/enu/CU/CU_EN_8_5_1_9.jsp|work=Korea Tourism Organization|accessdate=16 June 2012}} The venue was used by [[Asia League Ice Hockey]] team [[Daemyung Sangmu]] between 2013 and 2016. == See also == *[[Mokdong Baseball Stadium]] *[[Seoul Olympic Stadium]] *[[Hyochang Stadium]] *[[Dongdaemun Stadium]] *[[Seoul World Cup Stadium]] == References == {{reflist}} *[http://new.kleaguei.com/fan/ground/view.aspx?u=5623 The stadium of dreams in K-League : 제 3탄 목동 운동장 ① ] {{ko icon}} *[http://new.kleaguei.com/fan/ground/view.aspx?u=6189 The stadium of dreams in K-League : 제 3탄 목동 운동장 ② ] {{ko icon}} == External links == * [http://stadium.seoul.go.kr/reserve/mokdonggr/main-stadium Seoul Sports Facilities Management Center] {{ko icon}} * [http://www.visitseoul.net/en/article/article.do?_method=view&art_id=10907&lang=en&m=0004003002019&p=03 Mokdong Sports Stadium : Official Seoul City Tourism] {{en icon}} * [http://www.worldstadiums.com/stadium_pictures/asia/south_korea/seoul/seoul_mokdong.shtml World Stadiums] {{Jeju United FC}} {{FC Seoul}} {{coord|37|31|49.72|N|126|52|59.30|E|type:landmark|display=title}} [[Category:Football venues in South Korea]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1989]] [[Category:Sports venues in Seoul]] [[Category:Multi-purpose stadiums in South Korea]] {{SouthKorea-sports-venue-stub}} {{Asia-baseball-venue-stub}}

{{about|the youth baseball and softball organization|the professional baseball league founded in 1939 in Pennsylvania, Ontario, and New York|New York–Penn League}} {{Infobox sports league | logo = Pony League logo.png | pixels = 200 | caption = | sport = [[Baseball]] and [[softball]] | founded = 1951 | president = Abraham Key{{cite web |title=Abraham Key |url=http://www.pony.org/Default.aspx?tabid=1017281 |website=pony.org |accessdate=August 14, 2018}} | teams = | countries =United States, Mexico, Caribbean, Europe, Asia-Pacific | champion =[[Taipei County]]{{cite web |title=Taipei County, Taiwan wins Pony League World Series |url=http://www.pony.org/Default.aspx?tabid=899396&mid=974737&newskeyid=HN1&newsid=80049498&ctl=newsdetail |website=PONY Baseball and Softball |accessdate=12 September 2018 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180912141051/http://www.pony.org/Default.aspx?tabid=899396&mid=974737&newskeyid=HN1&newsid=80049498&ctl=newsdetail |archivedate=12 September 2018}}, [[Chinese Taipei]] | champ_season=2018 | most_champs ={{flagicon|California}} [[Long Beach, California|Long Beach, CA]] (4)
{{flagicon|Taiwan}} [[Taipei, Taiwan]] (3) | sponsor =[[Dick's Sporting Goods]] | tv =[[MLB.com]] | website = http://www.pony.org }} '''PONY Baseball and Softball''' is a [[non-profit organization]] with headquarters in [[Washington, Pennsylvania]]. Started in 1951, PONY organizes youth [[baseball]] and [[softball]] leagues and tournaments, as over 500,000 players annually play PONY in over 4,000 leagues throughout the United States and over 40 countries world-wide. The televised Pony League World Series held annually in August at Washington's Lew Hays Pony Field attracts teenage teams from around the world.{{cite news|last=Crawley|first=Dave |title=Teens Flock To Play Ball In Pony League World Series (August 5, 2016) |url=https://pittsburgh.cbslocal.com/2016/08/05/teens-flock-to-play-ball-in-pony-league-world-series/ |publisher=[[KDKA-TV]]|access-date=16 August 2017}} Membership is open to children and young adults from age 4 to 23 and the leagues are organized in two-year age brackets with "and-under" programs.{{cite web |url=http://www.pony.org/Default.aspx?tabid=1084932 |title=About PONY |website=pony.org |accessdate=August 14, 2018}} Hundreds of PONY players have gone on to [[Major League Baseball]] careers, including [[National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum|Hall of Fame]] inductees [[Tony Gwynn]] and [[Cal Ripken Jr.]]{{cite web |url=http://www.ovpb.net/content/15409/About-PONY |title=History Of Pony Baseball |website=ovpb.net |accessdate=August 14, 2018}} ==Origin of name== Children at the [[Washington, Pennsylvania]], [[YMCA]] named the organization PONY, which stood for "Protect Our Neighborhood Youth." This later became "Protect Our Nation's Youth." ==Levels of play== [[File:John Walls pitching opening day for the pony "West Covina Phantoms" in 2008 at age 14- 2013-12-23 02-06.jpg|thumb|right|A 14-year-old Pony League pitcher]] Distances shown are for baseball with players pitching; distances for other offerings (such as baseball with machine pitching, fast pitch softball, and slow pitch softball) may vary. {| class="wikitable" |- ! rowspan=2|League !! rowspan=2|Ages !! colspan=2|Distances !! rowspan=2|Ref. |- ! Bases !! Pitching |- | Shetland ||  6 and under || {{convert|50|ft|m|sigfig=4}} || {{convert|38|ft|m|sigfig=4}} || {{cite web |url=http://www.pony.org/Default.aspx?tabid=1025829 |title=SHETLAND 6U™ LEAGUE |website=pony.org |accessdate=August 14, 2018}} |- | Pinto ||  8 and under|| rowspan=2|{{convert|60|ft|m|sigfig=4}} || {{convert|40|ft|m|sigfig=4}} || {{cite web |url=http://www.pony.org/Default.aspx?tabid=1025841 |title=PINTO 8U™ LEAGUE |website=pony.org |accessdate=August 14, 2018}} |- | Mustang || 10 and under || {{convert|46|ft|m|sigfig=4}} || {{cite web |url=http://www.pony.org/Default.aspx?tabid=1099269 |title=MUSTANG 10U™ INFORMATION |website=pony.org |accessdate=August 14, 2018}} |- | Bronco || 12 and under || {{convert|70|ft|m|sigfig=4}} || {{convert|50|ft|m|sigfig=4}} || {{cite web |url=http://www.pony.org/Default.aspx?tabid=1099271 |title=BRONCO 12U™ INFORMATION |website=pony.org |accessdate=August 14, 2018}} |- | Pony || 14 and under || {{convert|80|ft|m|sigfig=4}} || {{convert|54|ft|m|sigfig=4}} || {{cite web |url=http://www.pony.org/Default.aspx?tabid=1025872 |title=PONY 14U™ LEAGUE |website=pony.org |accessdate=August 14, 2018}} |- | Colt || 16 and under || rowspan=3|{{convert|90|ft|m|sigfig=4}} || rowspan=3|{{convert|60|ft|6|in|m|sigfig=4}} || {{cite web |url=http://www.pony.org/Default.aspx?tabid=1025876 |title=COLT 16U™ LEAGUE |website=pony.org |accessdate=August 14, 2018}} |- | Palomino || 18 and under || {{cite web |url=http://www.pony.org/Default.aspx?tabid=1025882 |title=PALOMINO 18U™ LEAGUE |website=pony.org |accessdate=August 14, 2018}} |- | Thorobred || 23 and under || {{cite web |url=http://www.pony.org/Default.aspx?tabid=1025886 |title=THOROBRED 23U™ LEAGUE |website=pony.org |accessdate=August 14, 2018}} |} ==Pony League World Series champions== The Pony League World Series is the flagship tournament of PONY Baseball and Softball. After the creation of the organization in 1951, there were already 505 teams across 106 leagues the following year. This prompted PONY to create the Pony League World Series in [[Washington County, Pennsylvania]]. The finals did not have a set location and took place in various states, including California, Nebraska, Texas, Illinois, Iowa, and Washington. In 1981, World Series Tournaments, Incorporated (WSTI) was put in charge of running the tournament and fixed the location to Washington County, Pennsylvania. The first international team to appear in 1968, when both [[Venezuela]] and [[British Columbia|British Columbia, Canada]], made appearances. The first non-[[Americas]] team to appear was [[Japan]] in 1986. The tournament is now sponsored by [[Dick's Sporting Goods]] and the games are streamed on [[MLB.com]],{{Cite web|url=https://www.mlb.com/video/pony-world-series/c-2355478983?tid=86077464|title=PONY World Series {{!}} 08/14/2018|website=MLB.com|language=en|access-date=2018-08-14}} the official site of [[Major League Baseball]]. The recent finals can also be found on [[YouTube]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCCaj-1cTdTYkXj4Wmz-2VtA|title=PONY Baseball and Softball|website=YouTube|language=en|access-date=2018-08-14}} The format of the tournament has differed; for most years it has been [[Double-elimination tournament|double-elimination]], while at least the first tournament (1952) was [[Single-elimination tournament|single-elimination]], and the finals were a [[best of three]] at least twice during the 1970s. [[File:Pony_League_World_Series_logo.png|thumb|right|upright|Pony League World Series logo]] {| class="wikitable" border="1" cellpadding="2" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 90%; text-align: left;" |- !Year !Winner !Score !Runner–Up !Ref. |- |1952 |{{flagicon|Texas}} San Antonio, Texas |2–1 |{{flagicon|Massachusetts}} Brockton, Massachusetts |{{cite news |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/22899393/san_antonio_nips_brockton_21_for_pony/ |title=San Antonio Nips Brockton 2-1 for Pony League Title |agency=[[Associated Press|AP]] |newspaper=[[The Boston Globe]] |page=47 |date=August 17, 1952 |accessdate=August 17, 2018 |via=newspapers.com}} |- style="background: #D0E6FF;" |1953 |{{flagicon|West Virginia}} Fairmont, West Virginia |7–6 |{{flagicon|South Carolina}} North Charleston, South Carolina |{{cite news |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/22899531/pony_league_title_won_by_fairmont/ |title=Pony League Title Won By Fairmont |agency=[[Associated Press|AP]] |newspaper=[[The Herald-Mail|The Morning Herald]] |location=[[Hagerstown, Maryland]] |page=12 |date=August 22, 1953 |accessdate=August 17, 2018 |via=newspapers.com}} |- {{For|the settlement in Western Cape, South Africa|Polocross, Western Cape}} [[File:Polocrosse 3.jpg|thumb|300px|Playing polocrosse in [[New South Wales]], Australia - Photo - Andrew Muir No.1 Attack - Quirindi Club Final]] [[File:Polocrosse 1.jpg|thumb|Juniors playing polocrosse in NSW, Australia]] [[File:Polocrosse 2.jpg|thumb|Playing polocrosse in NSW, Australia]]
'''Polocrosse''' is a team sport that is a combination of [[polo]] and [[lacrosse]]. It is played outside, on a field (the pitch), on horseback. Each rider uses a cane or fibreglass stick to which is attached a racquet head with a loose, thread net, in which the ball is carried. The ball is made of sponge rubber and is approximately four inches across. The objective is to score goals by throwing the ball between the opposing team's goal posts.
The next Polocrosse World Cup will be held in Warwick Australia in 2019, the last World Cup was won in 2015 by South Africa
==Rules== Unlike polo, players are allowed only to play one horse, except in the case of injury. There is no restriction on the horse's height, although polocrosse horses are generally smaller than 16hh. Horses of all breeds play polocrosse and the [[Australian Stock Horse]] is the most popular breed playing in Australia. Stallions are not permitted to play.<ref name="Mather">Mather, Jill, "Forgotten Heroes – The Australian Waler horse", Bookbound Publishing, Ourimbah, NSW, {{ISBN|978-0-9803527-0-2}}</ref>
A team consists of six players, divided into two sections of three who each play either 2, 3 or 4 chukkas of six to eight minutes, depending on the rules of the tournament, with the two sections from each team alternating on and off the field each chukka. A match comprises four, six or eight chukkas. The three players in each section play the position of a No. 1, attack, a No. 2, midfield (a combination of defence and offence), or a No. 3, defence.<ref name="Rules"/>
The team structure was designed to force players to pass the ball about amongst themselves, making it a better skilled, faster sport.
The field is {{convert|60|x|160|yd|m}}, with three separate areas. The goal scoring areas, on each end, are 30 yards long. Only the No. 1 of the attacking team and the No. 3 of the defending team can play in these areas.<ref name="Rules">Polocrosse Association of Australia, Polocrosse Rules, Griffin Press, Adelaide</ref>
The middle area is 100 yards long. The line separating the goal scoring and centre areas is called the penalty or thirty-yard line. Goal posts are eight feet apart. To score, the ball must be thrown from outside an 11-yard semicircle in front of the goal.<ref name="Rules"/>
Players can pick up the ball from the ground, catch it in their racquet, and ride with it. They throw it to other players until the No.1 has possession in the goal scoring area. A player cannot carry the ball over the penalty line, but must bounce it so that they do not have possession of it while actually crossing the line. It can also be passed to a player over the line.<ref name="Rules"/>
When carrying the ball, a player must carry it on the stick side, i.e. right-handed players must carry it on the offside of the horse (if a person has possession of the ball and crosses the racket over the centre-line of the horse (the line that runs from the horses ears to the tail) it is a foul). A player can, however, pick-up or catch the ball on the non-stick side provided they immediately bring it back to their stick side.<ref name="Rules"/>
Each chukka begins with a line up at a central spot on the side boundary line in centre field. The players from each team line up in single file, facing the umpire at the edge of the field, with the No. 1s in front, followed by the 2's and then the 3's. The umpire then throws the ball between the players, between shoulder and racket height so that all players have a chance to catch the ball. The teams always line up on the defensive side of one another.<ref name="Rules"/>
The game recommences similarly after a goal has been scored, with the line up taking place on the alternate side of the field for every goal that is scored. Whenever an attempt at goal fails (i.e. a missed shot at goal), the No. 3 is awarded a 10-yard throw from the 30 yard line.<ref name="Rules"/>
The most common award given in the case of a penalty is a 10-yard throw. Where the foul occurred determines the position on the field at which the throw is taken. Depending on the nature of the penalty, the 10 yard throw may be taken at the spot where the penalty occurred or it may be moved down the field to the next 30 yard line to advantage the fouled team. For example, if the team carrying the ball is fouled, the penalty will most likely be moved down the field to give advantage to the fouled team, however if the team carrying the ball commits the foul the ball may just be turned over to the other team at the point where the foul occurred.<ref name="Rules"/>
Not all fouls are punished with a ten-yard throw. Particularly dangerous fouls (such as hitting another player in the head or helmet with the racket) result in a free goals being awarded. If a player continues to commit fouls after being cautioned by the umpire, commits a particularly dangerous or intentional foul, or generally behaves dangerously, the umpire can dismiss the player from the field.
If both teams are responsible for a penalty, or if the ball goes out of bounds after being deflected off a horse, the game is restarted with a line up. If the penalty occurs when the ball is in the end zone, the umpire will call a line up from within the area, between the attacking 1 and defending 3 players. If the penalty occurs when the ball is in centre field the game is restarted with a line up at the nearest sideline.
It is also illegal to ride through the goal posts, if any player's horse steps all 4 legs through the posts, it is an automatic free goal to the opposing team.
Players can get the ball from the opposition by hitting at an opponent's stick in an upwards direction only, with the swing starting from below the horses quarters when swing is forward, or below the horses withers when the swing is backward. This is done either to dislodge the ball or to prevent the opposition from gaining possession of it. This is called "giving wood". Riding off is also allowed, but crossing, stopping over the ball, or elbowing all constitute fouls. Sandwiching one player between two others also constitutes a foul.
==History== The modern game was developed in Australia before the [[Second World War]]. In 1938 Mr. and Mrs. Edward Hirst of Sydney read an article in an English Horse Magazine on Polo Crosse. As both were keen on horse breeding and horse sports they decided to find out more about it when they got to England. On arrival, they visited the National School of Equitation at [[Kingston Vale]] near [[London]], where two instructors had developed an exercise to supplement the work at the riding School and help young riders take better charge of their horses.<ref>{{cite encyclopedia | title = Chisholm, Alec H. | encyclopedia = The Australian Encyclopaedia | volume = | pages = | publisher = Halstead Press | location = Sydney | year = 1963 | id = | accessdate = 8 August 2008 }} </ref>
The exercise was played indoors with two riders a side and markers on the wall from which the ball bounced back into play. The goals were elongated basketball nets hung at each end of the arena. The sticks were old polo sticks that had the polo mallet removed and replaced with a squash racquet head. This had a shallow string net, which they used to scoop up the ball. The idea was to scoop up the ball, which was a little larger than a tennis ball, ride with it to the end of the arena and drop it into the net to score.
Realising the possibilities of this exercise as an outdoor horse sport, the couple returned to Australia with sticks, balls and rule books where they sought the assistance of Alf Pitty, a well known horseman and polo player.
After many hours of discussion, practising, and much trial and error and with constant revision of the rules, they finally came up with a new and exciting game using only one horse and able to be played by a person of any age. They called the new game Polocrosse.
After all their careful designing, Pitty then helped to give the first recorded polocrosse demonstration at Ingleburn Sports Ground near [[Sydney]] in 1939. Interest and enthusiasm was so great that it was not long before all the club members were practising this new game. A short time later in 1939 a meeting was called at [[Ingleburn, New South Wales|Ingleburn]] to form the first Polocrosse Club. At this meeting the first book of the rules of the game was established. Burradoo was the next polocrosse club to be made in Australia and is now the longest running club in Australia.
In 1962 [[Walcha, New South Wales|Walcha]] became the first club team to win the Lennon trophy at the [[Australian Red Cross]] championships at [[Maitland]] when the four Goodwin brothers, Paul, Maurice, Noel and Brian together with Bob Gill and John Nixon played as the North [[New England]] No 1 team.<ref>Maitland Mercury newspaper, 4/5 August 1962</ref>
Polocrosse in [[South Africa]] started in the early 1950s. The first International tour of South Africa was in 1968 by [[Rhodesia]] and followed by the Australians in 1971. Polocrosse finally made it back to the [[United Kingdom]] in 1978, when it was introduced to two branches of the Pony Club in [[Surrey]]. It continued to be played at Pony Club level, with its popularity slowly growing. The arrival of polocrosse players from [[Zimbabwe]] (formerly Rhodesia) and [[South Africa]] in the UK in the early 1980s led to the establishment of polocrosse clubs outside of the Pony Club and in 1985 the UK Polocrosse Association was formed. Polocrosse became an official Pony Club activity with its own championship at around the same time. Polocrosse is also played in [[Finland]], [[France]], [[Germany]], [[New Zealand]], the [[United States]], [[Canada]], [[Norway]], the [[Netherlands]], [[Papua New Guinea]], [[Indonesia]], [[Uruguay]], [[Vanuatu]], [[Zimbabwe]], [[United Kingdom]], [[Zambia]] and [[Italy]]. <ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.polocrosse.net/component/option,com_frontpage/Itemid,1/|title= Polocrosse Worldwide|accessdate=4 June 2008 |author= |date= |work= |publisher=}}</ref>
== Polocrosse in Ireland == {{Unreferenced section|date=June 2011}} In 1990 polocrosse came to [[Ireland]]. Brothers, David and Ivor Young introduced Polocrosse to Ireland in 1990 as an additional tourism attraction to their residential equestrian holiday business in Co. Wexford. David had just read an article on Polocrosse in a UK [[Equestrianism|Equestrian]] Magazine. Interested to learn more about this exciting game, the two brothers had an Australian coach (Bernie Uechtritz) at Horetown House some five weeks later. In the early stages, the game was only played at Horetown House, [[Co. Wexford]] but it wasn’t long before Brian McMahon of Rathcannon in [[Co. Limerick]] heard about this new game, and Limerick Polocrosse Club was the next club to be established. From here polocrosse expanded rapidly in Ireland, with several other clubs springing up around Ireland, including, Tipperary (based in Clonmel, Co. Tipperary), Carrickmines (Based in South Dublin), Waterford (based in Tramore, Co.Waterford), Birr (Based in Birr Co.Offaly) and three new recent additions the Cork Club (based on Hop Island, Co.Cork), Tyrella (Based in Tyrella Co.Down) and Equus (Based in South Dublin).

Moussac.svg | alt3 = Yellow and black hoops, yellow cap | caption3 = Acteur Francais }} {{Jockey colours footer}} The '''Prix Morny''' is a [[Group races|Group 1]] [[Flat racing|flat]] [[Horse racing|horse race]] in France open to two-year-old [[thoroughbred]] [[Colt (horse)|colts]] and [[Filly|fillies]]. It is run at [[Deauville-La Touques Racecourse|Deauville]] over a distance of 1,200 metres (about 6 furlongs), and it is scheduled to take place each year in August. ==History== The event is named in memory of [[Charles de Morny, Duke of Morny|Auguste de Morny]] (1811–1865), the founder of Deauville Racecourse. It was established in 1865, and it was originally called the Prix ''de'' Morny. The inaugural race was over 1,000 metres, and the prize for the winning owner was 9,150 francs. The second and third runnings of the Prix de Morny were contested over 1,200 metres. It was extended to 1,300 metres in 1868, and to 1,400 metres in 1870. The race became known as the Prix de Deux Ans in 1871, and its distance was cut to 1,200 metres in 1887. It was renamed the Prix Morny, a shortened version of its original title, in 1911. The Prix Morny was abandoned from 1914 to 1918, and again in 1940. Its usual venue was closed during World War II, so it was held temporarily at [[Longchamp Racecourse|Longchamp]] (1941–42, 1944) and [[Maisons-Laffitte Racecourse|Maisons-Laffitte]] (1943, 1945). The first two editions at Longchamp were run over 1,000 metres, and the 1944 running was contested over 1,300 metres. The event opened to foreign horses in 1947, and that year's race was won by a British colt named Delirium. An earlier spell as an international race (1875 to 1908) had yielded no foreign winners. ==Records== '''Leading [[jockey]] (10 wins):''' * [[George Stern]] – ''Eperon (1900), Farnus (1901), Vinicius (1902), Val d'Or (1904), Mehari (1908), Porte Maillot (1911), Marka (1912), Durzetta (1920), Zariba (1921), Banstar (1925)'' ---- '''Leading [[Horse trainer|trainer]] (8 wins):''' * Robert Denman – ''Present Times (1884), Frapotel (1886), Farnus (1901), Vinicius (1902), Val d'Or (1904), Mehari (1908), Porte Maillot (1911), Marka (1912)'' ---- '''Leading owner (13 wins):''' * [[Marcel Boussac]] – ''Durzetta (1920), Zariba (1921), Banstar (1925), Cecias (1932), Corrida (1934), Semiramide (1938), Esmeralda (1941), Coaraze (1944), Nirgal (1945), Cadir (1946), Auriban (1951), Cordova (1953), Apollonia (1955)'' ==Winners since 1968== {| class = "sortable" | border="1" style="border-collapse: collapse; font-size:90%" |- bgcolor="#77dd77" align="center" ! In [[gridiron football]], a '''shift''' refers to the movement of an [[offense (sports)|offensive]] player prior to the [[snap (football)|snap]]. == Motion and shift ==
There is a distinction drawn between a ''shift'' and ''motion'' in football. [[Motion (gridiron football)|Motion]] occurs when a player is moving ''at the time of the snap''. A shift occurs when one or more players changes their position on the offensive side of the ball ''before the snap'', causing a change in formation. For example, players may line up initially in an [[I-formation]] and then shift the two running backs into wide receiver positions to put the offense in a [[spread formation]]. A team may shift any number of players into new positions, so long as they all come to a complete stop for a full second before the ball is snapped to start the play.
The National Football League defines all motion and shift penalties as "illegal motion",<ref>[http://static.nfl.com/static/content/public/image/rulebook/pdfs/24_Penalty_Summary.pdf NFL official rule book]</ref> while both the NCAA and NFHSAA make a distinction between an "illegal shift" and "illegal motion"; an illegal shift refers to players shifting and not coming to a complete stop before the snap while illegal motion refers to a player who is in motion towards the line of scrimmage, or a player who is not a "back" in motion.<ref>[http://www.ncaapublications.com/productdownloads/FR12.pdf NCAA official football rules]</ref> In both leagues, however, the penalty for illegal motion/illegal shift is five yards from the previous spot and replay the down.
Additionally, the offensive team may be charged with the penalty of a "false start" if a player on the offense jumps or moves abruptly, simulating the start of the play. This movement is not normally considered a subset of the "motion" or "shift" rules, as the player is not judged to be moving into a new pre-snap position; they are merely starting the play too soon. This is also a five yard penalty. ==History== [[File:Heismanatshift.jpg|thumb|150px|Diagram of the Heisman shift.]] Both motions and shift were introduced by [[Amos Alonzo Stagg]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5pPYAODf6ZAC&pg=PA204&lpg=PA204#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=Football|publisher=}}</ref> The history of [[college football]] involves three notable, distinct shifts: *The [[Minnesota shift]], used by the likes of [[Henry L. Williams]]. *The [[Jump shift]] or Heisman shift, used by the likes of [[John Heisman]]. *The [[Notre Dame Box]], used by the likes of [[Knute Rockne]].
==References== {{reflist}} {{Gridiron football maneuvers}} [[Category:American football terminology]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2011}} {{Use Australian English|date=April 2011}} {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = 1300SMILES Stadium | nickname = | logo_image = [[File:1300SMILES Stadium.jpg|300px]] | image = 14-05-2005-dairy farmers at dusk.JPG | image_size = 300px | location = Golf Links Drive, [[Kirwan, Queensland]] | coordinates = {{coord|19|18|58|S|146|42|43|E|display=it}} | broke_ground = 1994 | opened = 1994 | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Queensland Government]] | operator = Major Sports Facilities Authority | surface = Grass | construction_cost = [[Australian dollar|A$]]11.03 million (2005–06 redevelopment) | architect = | former_names = Willows Sports Complex
Stockland Stadium
Malanda Stadium
Dairy Farmers Stadium | tenants = [[North Queensland Cowboys]] (1995–present)
[[Northern Fury FC|North Queensland Fury]] (2009–2011) | seating_capacity = 26,500 | record_attendance = 30,302 – Cowboys vs [[Brisbane Broncos|Brisbane]], 1999 |}} The '''Willows Sports Complex''', currently known as '''1300SMILES Stadium''' through [[Naming rights|sponsorship]], is a grass [[football]] stadium situated in [[Townsville]], [[Queensland]], [[Australia]]. It has been a predominantly [[rugby league]] ground as the home ground of the [[North Queensland Cowboys]] [[National Rugby League]] club. The ground has also been used for [[rugby union]] and [[soccer]]. From 2009 to 2011, [[A-League]] football club [[Northern Fury FC|North Queensland Fury]] called it home. Since inception as a rugby league ground, the ground has had sponsored naming rights: '''Stockland Stadium''' (1995–97), '''Malanda Stadium''' (1998) and '''Dairy Farmers Stadium''' (1999–2013). == History == {{Unreferenced section|date=May 2008}} ===Willows Sporting Complex=== Prior to 1995, the stadium site was occupied by the Willows Sporting Complex. It hosted trotting paceway nights, and was the main pacing venue for the Townsville District. With the admission of the North Queensland Cowboys to the [[Australian Rugby League]] competition in 1995, the Willows site was transformed into a basic rugby league venue with a western grandstand as well as eastern side terraces. The northern and southern ends had sloped grass hills. ===Stockland Stadium=== The Willows Sports Complex was renamed "Stockland Stadium" in 1995 through sponsorship linked with the [[North Queensland Cowboys]]. A contract was signed by the Stockland Trust Group for three years giving them the naming rights of the venue. The Joint Board of the old Willows Sports Complex ([[City of Townsville|Townsville City Council]] and [[City of Thuringowa|Thuringowa City Council]]) sub-leased the facility to the Cowboys Rugby League Football Limited, who manage the venue on a day-to-day basis. The first stage of development was funded by a combination of borrowings by the Joint Board, the [[Queensland Government]] Grants and a considerable amount of community and business donations. The stadium was first used for any type of football for the North Queensland Cowboys first home game which attracted a crowd of 23,156, a good crowd by [[Australian Rugby League]] (now [[National Rugby League]]) standards. Crowds continued to push the capacity of the stadium and in 1996 Stockland Stadium was renovated to include both northern and southern seating, where previously there had been only standing room. Stockland Stadium had the honour of hosting the first ever game of the [[1997 Super League (Australia) season|inaugural]] (and only) [[Super League (Australia)|Super League season]] on 1 March 1997 when the Cowboys hosted new team the [[Adelaide Rams]] in front of 17,738 fans. After trailing 16–4 at half time the Cowboys eventually prevailed 24–16.[http://www.rugbyleagueproject.org/seasons/super-league-1997/round-1/north-queensland-vs-adelaide/summary.html 1997 Super League - North Queensland vs Adelaide] Stockland ended their sponsorship after three years, which paved the way for long-term sponsor, Dairy Farmers Limited. ===Malanda Stadium=== The [[North Queensland Cowboys]] home stadium sponsor [[Stockland (company)|Stockland]] finished up their sponsorship contract seeing out their three-year deal. A new sponsorship deal was drawn up by the Cowboys, with local milking organisation Dairy Farmers who owned the local [[Tropical North Queensland|North Queensland]] milking dairy in the [[Malanda, Queensland|Tablelands]]. Season 1998 saw the stadium renamed with a new sponsorship deal "Malanda Stadium". Following the purchase of Malanda Milk by [[Dairy Farmers]], the ground was renamed "Dairy Farmers Stadium". ===Dairy Farmers Stadium=== Many stages of redevelopment were taken on and gradually completed over the Cowboys growing success. The venue had changed from a disused Harness Racing facility to the current complex. The management and operation of the stadium was handed over to [http://www.stadiums.qld.gov.au/ Stadiums Queensland] in December 2003 in the hope for more cash inflow and government spending. In 2005 the eastern terraces were extended, a new replay screen invested, public address system installed, 30 more corporate boxes and upgraded catering facilities as part of the funding injection. The lighting facilities were upgraded for night time broadcasts. 2006 saw the eastern, northern and southern grandstands receiving even further upgrades with the fitting of extra seating and the eastern terrace was extended completely taking over the old eastern hill. Two of [[Papua New Guinea national rugby league team|Papua New Guinea]]'s [[2008 Rugby League World Cup Group A]] games were played at Dairy Farmers Stadium, one against [[England national rugby league team|England]] and the other against [[Australia national rugby league team|Australia]]. During the [[2011 NRL season]] a capacity crowd attended [[Darren Lockyer]]'s record-setting 350th NRL match at Dairy Farmer's.{{cite news|last=Margie|first=McDonald|title=Darren Lockyer's magical history tour just keeps rolling on|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/sport/darren-lockyers-magical-history-tour-just-keeps-rolling-on/story-e6frg7mf-1226114103202|accessdate=13 August 2011|newspaper=[[The Australian]]|date=13 August 2011}} ===1300SMILES Stadium=== It was announced on 19 February 2013 that 1300SMILES had signed a five-year deal for naming rights, bringing Dairy Farmers' fifteen years to an end.[http://www.austadiums.com/news/news.php?id=512 1300SMILES for Townsville Stadium | Austadiums] 1300SMILES is an Australian dentistry business headquartered in Townsville. ==Proposed replacement== A heavily redeveloped stadium was featured as part of Australia's [[2022 FIFA World Cup]] bid. The planning for the bid identified several issues with the existing stadium, particularly sub standard facilities, congestion and limited transport access. Stadiums Queensland identified that some form of redevelopment or replacement was necessary regardless of the failed World Cup bid. In 2011, the Cowboys in conjunction with Stadiums Queensland developed a $185 million plan to replace the ageing Dairy Farmers Stadium. The proposed ground would be located at the Saunders Street QR National site close to the Townsville CBD, as part of an urban renewal plan. The existing QR National rail yards are to be relocated in accordance with the Townsville Port Authority Master Plan 2010–2040.[http://www.townsvillebulletin.com.au/article/2011/08/27/261391_news.html No Cookies | Townsville Bulletin] The proposed ground is to seat 30,000 fans, including two 450 seat function rooms, 100 open air corporate boxes and 25 enclosed boxes. ==Attendance records== {| class="wikitable" |- style="background:#bdb76b;" ! Crowd !! Date !! Event !! Sport |- | 30,302 || 29 April 1999|| {{leagueicon|Nth Qld|16}} [[North Queensland Cowboys]] v. {{leagueicon|Brisbane|16}} [[Brisbane Broncos]] || Rugby league |- | 30,250 || 8 August 1998 || {{leagueicon|Nth Qld|16}} North Queensland Cowboys v. {{leagueicon|Brisbane|16}} Brisbane Broncos || Rugby league |- | 30,122 || 5 April 1997 || {{leagueicon|Nth Qld|16}} North Queensland Cowboys v. {{leagueicon|Brisbane|16}} Brisbane Broncos || Rugby league |} ==Uses== ===Rugby league=== 1300SMILES Stadium is predominantly used as a [[Rugby league playing field|rugby league ground]], being the home ground of the North Queensland Cowboys in the National Rugby League competition, and the North Queensland Young Guns in the [[Queensland Cup]] competition. The stadium has also hosted an [[Australian national rugby league team|Australian]] Test match against [[Papua New Guinea national rugby league team|Papua New Guinea]] in 2000, an Australian XIII match in 2005, the [[Super League (Australia)|Super League]] World 9's tournament in 1997 and charity fixtures with State of Origin Legend matches and Australia Legends v New Zealand Legends. It also hosted England vs Papua New Guinea in the 2008 Rugby League World Cup. With 2012 being an [[2012 Summer Olympics|Olympic year]] and the games being held in [[London]], the annual [[Rugby League Four Nations]], usually held at the end of the NRL season, was not scheduled as a result. This has resulted in an end of year test between Australia and [[New Zealand Kiwis|New Zealand]] being scheduled to be held at the Dairy Farmers Stadium on 13 October for its first international match since the 2008 World Cup. ====Rugby League Test Matches==== List of rugby league test matches played at the stadium.[http://www.rugbyleagueproject.org/venues/willows-sports-complex/results.html Willows Sports Complex results @ Rugby League Project] {| class="wikitable" |- style="background:#bdb76b;" ! Test# !! Date !! Result !! Attendance !! Notes |- |1 || 7 October 2000 || {{rl|AUS}} def. {{rl|PNG}} 82–0 || 21,000 || |- |2 || 25 October 2008 || {{rl|ENG}} def. {{rl|PNG}} 32–22 || 10,780 || [[2008 Rugby League World Cup|2008]] [[Rugby League World Cup]] [[2008 Rugby League World Cup Group A|Group A]] |- |3 || 8 November 2008 || {{rl|AUS}} def. {{rl|PNG}} 46–6 || 16,239 || [[2008 Rugby League World Cup|2008]] [[Rugby League World Cup]] [[2008 Rugby League World Cup Group A|Group A]] |- |4 || 13 October 2012 || {{rl|AUS}} def. {{rl|NZL}} 18–10 || 26,497 || |- |5 || 28 October 2017 || {{rl|FIJ}} def. {{rl|USA}} 58–12 || 5,103 || [[2017 Rugby League World Cup|2017]] [[Rugby League World Cup]] [[2017 Rugby League World Cup Group D|Group D]] |- |6 || 5 November 2017 || {{rl|ITA}} def. {{rl|USA}} 46-0 || 7,732|| [[2017 Rugby League World Cup|2017]] [[Rugby League World Cup]] [[2017 Rugby League World Cup Group D|Group D]] |- |7 || 5 November 2017 || {{rl|FIJ}} def. {{rl|WAL}} 72-6 || 7,732 || [[2017 Rugby League World Cup|2017]] [[Rugby League World Cup]] [[2017 Rugby League World Cup Group D#Fiji v Wales .28Intra-Group.29|Inter-group match]] |} ===Rugby union=== The stadium was first used for first class [[rugby union]] when the touring British and Irish Lions team played a Queensland President's XV team in 2001. In 2003 a number of matches, which involved [[Japan national rugby union team|Japan]] in the [[2003 Rugby Union World Cup|Rugby Union World Cup]] were played at the ground, averaging a crowd of 19,249.[http://www.austadiums.com/stadiums/stadiums_crowds.php?id=40 1300SMILES Stadium Crowds (Townsville Stadium) | Austadiums] On 12 May 2006 the [[Queensland Reds]] played a [[Super Rugby|Super 14]] match at Dairy Farmers Stadium in front of a crowd of 10,580.[http://foxsports.news.com.au/story/0,8659,19117845-23210,00.html Home | Live Scores & Latest News | Fox Sports] In June 2007 the stadium hosted Australia A and Japan in the IRB Pacific Nations Cup. ====Rugby World Cup==== The Willows Sports Complex hosted three Pool B games from the [[2003 Rugby World Cup|2003]] [[Rugby World Cup]] which was held in Australia. {|class="wikitable" ! Date ! Competition !colspan=2| Home team !colspan=2| Away team ! Attendance |- |12 October 2003 || [[2003 Rugby World Cup|2003]] [[Rugby World Cup]] Pool B || {{ru|SCO}} || 33 || {{ru|JPN}} || 11 || 19,170 |- |18 October 2003 || [[2003 Rugby World Cup|2003]] [[Rugby World Cup]] Pool B || {{ru|FRA}} || 51 || {{ru|JPN}} || 29 || 21,309 |- |23 October 2003 || [[2003 Rugby World Cup|2003]] [[Rugby World Cup]] Pool B || {{ru|FIJ}} || 41 || {{ru|JPN}} || 13 || 17,269 |} ===Football (Soccer)=== * [[Australia]]n [[Olyroos]] soccer friendly. * In 2009, 1300SMILES Stadium became home to Townsville's new club, the [[North Queensland Fury FC|North Queensland Fury]] who played in the [[A-League]], the nation's premier soccer competition. Their licence was revoked in March 2011. ===Other=== * [[Kostya Tszyu]]'s World Title boxing qualifier * [[Cricket]] Super 8's state championships * [[Crusty Demons]] tour. * [[Elton John]] performed at Dairy Farmers Stadium on 4 December 2007, as part of his "Knight under the stars" tour. * [[Nitro Circus]] tour ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|1300SMILES Stadium}} *[http://www.dairyfarmersstadium.com.au/ Official website] *{{Austadiums|40}} {{NthQldCowboys}} {{NRL Grounds}} {{2008 RLWC Venues}} {{2003 Rugby World Cup venues}} {{A-League stadiums}} [[Category:Northern Fury FC]] [[Category:Rugby league stadiums in Australia]] [[Category:Rugby union stadiums in Australia]] [[Category:Rugby League World Cup stadiums]] [[Category:Rugby World Cup stadiums]] [[Category:A-League stadiums]] [[Category:1994 establishments in Australia]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1994]] [[Category:Sports venues in Townsville]] [[Category:Queensland Reds]]
